head.description: Searches for recent and upcoming public events hosted by Meetup groups. Its search window is the past one month through the next three months, and is subject to change. Open Events is optimized to search for current events by location, category, topic, or text, and only lists Meetups that have **3 or more RSVPs**. The number or results returned with each request is not guaranteed to be the same as the page size due to secondary filtering. If you\'re looking for a particular event or events within a particular group, use the standard [Events](/meetup_api/docs/2/events/) method.
head.title: Meetup Open Events v2

item.description:
\xc2\xa0

FCCP Weekly

Photo Assignment

\xc2\xa0

Week 75

\xc2\xa0

Topic: Churches

\xc2\xa0

Please only upload one (1) image

\xc2\xa0

The submitted image must be shot

during the week of the assignment

\n\nFollowing in the tradition of some of the great photo documentary magazines we are starting a weekly assignment project. Every Wednesday a new assignment with a topic will be posted. You\'ll have one week or in some cases less to complete the assignment.

What is an assignment? An assignment is shooting a series of photos that conform to the theme or topic for the week. Then reviewing the photos and uploading the one best photo that meets the requirements of the topic.

Once you have completed the assignment and upload your one best shot to the album created for the event. Please only post one image.

The purpose of a challenge is to encourage members to photograph subjects they may not normally\xc2\xa0photograph. \xc2\xa0By accepting the challenge they\'ll use photographic techniques and compositional\xc2\xa0techniques that they don\'t normally use. \xc2\xa0In return, they\'ll gain new insights and skills in photography.

Here are a few "Churches" photos to get you thinking.

Please only upload one (1) image

\xc2\xa0
item.how_to_find_us: This is not an in person event. The assignment is completed within the dates above and posted to the photo gallery for the assignment
item.name: FCCP Week 75 Assignment: Assignment Topic: Churches

item.description:
Marketing 100.9

Have you ever wondered why businesses choose the colors they use in their branding? Have you ever wanted to develop a marketing piece that stands out from everyone else\xe2\x80\x99s and just sets you apart? Wonder why your promotional material looked great to you, but just didn\xe2\x80\x99t get the message across. Are you looking for free advertising? If you haven\xe2\x80\x99t been able to answer these questions then you won\xe2\x80\x99t want to miss this Marketing program by Michael Collins.

As Michael says, \xe2\x80\x9cNormally I would call this Marketing 101 but I have to be a little different.\xe2\x80\x9d Ok, so those that know me know that he is \xe2\x80\x9ca lot different.\xe2\x80\x9d Come have fun and learn a little in the process.\xe2\x80\x9d


Just a little background\xe2\x80\xa6
Michael Collins retired from Law Enforcement at the rank of Sergeant after 30 years of service in 2006. He has been a professional photographer for over 17 years and has served on the board of directors for the Professional Photographers of California becoming President in 2007-2008. He has also served as President of the Gold Coast Professional Photographers Association ten times.

He has received both his Fellowship and Service Medallions from PPC and his Master of Photography Medallion and Craftsman from PPA. He holds the Business in Arts Degree from PPC. Michael was also awarded the coveted Evans Kingham Award in 2010 from the Professional Photographers of California. He also was awarded the PPC Presidents Award in 2011.

Michael\xe2\x80\x99s passion in photography is mostly photographing high school seniors. As he
says, \xe2\x80\x9cI am at the same maturity level as they are and therefore it works for me.\xe2\x80\x9d He has
written several articles, published in both photographic and law enforcement magazines

group.name: Professional Photographers of The Sacramento Valley

item.name: Marketing 100.9 with Michael Collins

item.description:
Grab a cup of coffee and head out to Montrose Beach to capture the sunrise on the first day of spring. This is an awesome location to watch the sun come up! Sunrise is at\xc2\xa06:54 AM. Let's meet at 6:00. Look for us in the street\xc2\xa0directly\xc2\xa0in\xc2\xa0front of the vendor stand and main\xc2\xa0entrance\xc2\xa0to the beach. At 6:15 SHARP we will walk straight out onto the beach. If you arrive after 6:15, look for us out on the beach.

Here's a map where I marked the stand where we will meet:

Montrose Beach Sunrise Shoot

This is past the boat harbor...

There's a food vendor/restroom stand on N. Simonds Dr. just past the harbor. Not to be confused with the bait shop on the corner. It's directly in front of the Kathy Osterman Beach.

From there we can walk down to the beach. Parking is free, and plentiful.

Google map:

item.description:
Just because I hate winter doesn\'t mean other NENP members shouldn\'t be getting out and about to shoot. (Or, do as I have done with my series "A Tree Grows in Rexhame" and shoot from the comfort of your home. Just be prepared for a cold arctic blast if your house faces the NW as mine does. Those winds are something coming off the river and marsh.)

The album is open from the Winter Solstice, December 20, to the Spring Equinox, March 20. The Meetup software does not allow me to make the dates run longer than two weeks so I have put in the end date. Please feel free to add photos as you shoot them from now until then.

Only restriction, as always: your images must be shot after the sun goes down and before it comes up in the morning.

Though there are no limits to the number of photos you may post. However, in order to keep the album fresh and exciting, never post more than three images at once. We are looking for your BEST shots. If possible, please wait for another person to post before you continue.

Note: Photo albums, groups shoots, exhibits and events are for paying members only. I will remove photos if your dues are not current.
item.name: Self-Directed: Winter 2014, Share What You\'ve Done On Your Own Time

item.description:
Gibbs Gardens, less than an hour from Atlanta is nestled in the foothills of the North Georgia Mountains. Enjoy the serenity of nature and stroll along the streams with many waterfalls or around the water gardens with 22 reflecting ponds. Cross the bridges and refresh yourself with the beauty and fragrance of thousands of plants, flowers, and millions of bulbs that provide a wide array of color, shape and texture for the 16 garden venues. A mature, native woodland surrounds the gardens with the peace and tranquility of nature.

Here are the driving directions - http://gibbsgardens.com/directions.php

Please remember no food is allowed.

When purchasing tickets, please tell them you are with Jim Pettit to receive your discount.

See you there . . .

Jim

[masked]

group.name: Photo Field Trips with Jim Pettit

item.description:
HIKE: We will hike the Boise Foothills to the top of Table Rock.

INTERMEDIATE HIKE: 3.5-5 miles at a\xc2\xa0steady pace and 940 feet elevation gain.\xc2\xa0

OPTION: Hike a shorter distance by turning around when you need to.... making sure you notify the leader and the person you car pooled with. \xc2\xa0

ELEVATION:\xc2\xa02,750\'. Max\xc2\xa0Elevation: 2,690\'\xc2\xa0(gain of 940\')

TRAIL INFO: We will hike up from the trailhead behind the Bishop\xe2\x80\x99s House to the top of Table Rock for some great views and back down with an option of hiking to Castle Rock. This is a steady climb.

MEET: We will meet in the parking lot behind the Bishops House at 9:00 a.m. To find the parking lot, turn off Warm Springs Ave., north-east on Old Penitentiary rd. Turn left just before entering the penitentiary area, and follow that road a short distance to the parking lot behind the Bishops House. Watch for the group of smiling Baby Boomers.

RETURN TIME: We should be back to the parking lot by 11:00 a.m.

EVENT HOST:\xc2\xa0Dave Hopkins\xc2\xa0(473-0954). Harry will be covering for me on this one.

BRING: Adequate water, snacks, camera, and a smile.\xc2\xa0

RESTROOMS: none.

DOG CONTROL: Dogs, must be kept in control at all times... must be kept with-in verbal command at all times, must not run up and down the trail where hikers are hiking.\xc2\xa0

Please check this web site before heading out. We may have to change if the trails are muddy.

Your Safety Is Your Responsibility. By joining the hike you have accepted responsibility for your safety.
item.how_to_find_us: Watch for Dave\'s 1936 pickup in the parking lot behind the Bishops House.
item.name: Hike the Boise Foothills at Tablerock for the FIRST DAY OF SPRING!

item.description:
Intro

The Westminster Quay sits next to the Fraser River and connects with the Waterfront Esplanade Boardwalk. \xc2\xa0There is lots to see and photograph along the esplanade. \xc2\xa0Hopefully the weather will be on our side and we can enjoy a beautiful walk.\xc2\xa0After, we can meet for lunch at the pub and share our bits of wisdom. \xc2\xa0Or just hang out. \xc2\xa0Hopefully the sun will be out and we can sit outside. \xc2\xa0

The Walk-about:

We will meet at the Westminster Quay\xc2\xa0810 Quayside Drive in New Westminster\xc2\xa0at 10:30 am at the entrance to the food court area. \xc2\xa0Access to the Quay is by bus,\xc2\xa0sky train or car. \xc2\xa0Parking is available at the Quay for $1.50 for 2 hours or $5.50 for 12 hours

Skytrain \xc2\xa0www.translink.ca

The Aim

The function of the group is to learn and practice the techniques of photography. This involves learning photography not only from your guides but also by sharing knowledge with your group-mates. The intention is also to organize and get to know new people. The attendant size of the meets will be small so participants can have the opportunity to get to know all their group-mates and spend time with a guide.

If you select to attend a meet and then cannot make it, please be courteous to others in the group and change your RSVP status as soon as possible to allow others a chance to participate

The Apr\xc3\xa8s-Meet

Please feel comfortable in posting your photographs and advising others; critical appraisal is helpful. What will also be appreciated are ratings and, especially, comments to individual meets and the group dynamic as a whole. This is important because it will ultimately add value to our meetings and improve our experience.
item.how_to_find_us: Entrance to Food Court area
item.name: Westminster Quay: Rivers, Bridges, Marine Life, Parks, Structure, Plus!

item.description:
Rating:
\xc2\xa0 Moderate, lengthy--some rocky/sandy terrain, no shade. Distance is up to 8 miles, depending on what we find to explore.

Drive:
1.5 hours, and a $10 entrance fee per car.

Photo Ops: We\'ve picked what looks to be a riotous colorful route and we anticipate some early blooming cacti, too! Some may want to stay for the sunset @ 6:48 PM!


The planned route enters a rarely visited part of the park, and is said to be quite something by a mysterious little old man we met at the Fire Wave. Good enough for us!


This is one of our patented "Google Earth" scout hikes. We have not followed the route but we\'ve planned it out on Google Earth, and considering the very open nature of the area and the obvious color bands along most of the route, making fast progress in this eye-candy land should be no problem.


In case it\'s harder than we estimate, there are two good \'bail-out\' points that would each carve considerable milage off the hike. The first bail-out shortens the hike by 1/2 its length. Should be enough to keep us safe.


However, please don\'t assume that the short version is offered as a normal option. We would not like to see someone take a bail-out route alone, and we won\'t be doing it ourselves except in a clearly difficult situation. This is a scout hike.

The Route:
\xc2\xa0 The planned route goes east from the paved road at parking lot# 1, 1 mile past Rainbow turnoff, in the center of the main valley, traversing long stretches of colorful stone, with ridges, gullies, and whatever.(we will set up a shuttle after we gather at parking lot#1 @ 12:45 pm Nevada time, the start from parking lot#1as our beginning TH)

Then we pass thru a small set of rock hills, finding the funnest route. Descending from them, we slip thru a v-shaped water gap in a hard tilted layer.

Then having entered East VOF proper, it\'s time for some fun exploring in various color layers, eventually going north a few miles along these tilted layers. We\'ll pass around the east side of a big hill and curve west back towards the road and finally arrive at Lot 3, the one near the Fire Wave.

Finally we will take our pre-positioned shuttle cars back down the paved park road two miles to the starting trailhead. Okay, shuttling is a pain, but it\'s short, colorful, and saves two miles of walking.


Prep:
The usual for the spring desert; stout boots, gloves, hat, LOTS of water, some food, and a hunger for rough but striking desert vistas.

Meetup:
\xc2\xa0 Meet at Noon in the Walmart parking lot, between wallyworld and Dickies BBQ. The drive to the trailhead is about 1.5 hours. There will be a two mile shuttle along the paved park road to save some walking.

See you there!

VOF Brochure:

http://parks.nv.gov/wp-content/uploads/2012/01/2012-VofF-screen.pdf

group.name: CLICK Photography Club of St. George, Utah

item.name: Explore (Lesser Known) Colorful East Side of Valley of Fire~Scout Hike

item.description:
Walk length 2 miles/3.2 km approx. Circular.

A chance to explore the largest park in Islington, Highbury Fields and the fascinating history that surrounds it.

Highbury fields is surrounded by fabulous terraces and squares, many associated with such people as John Wesley, Joseph Chamberlain, Thomas Cubitt and Charles Alfred Cruft.\xc2\xa0 The former sites of Highbury Manor, Highbury Barn and Arsenal Stadium are also close.

Although not a full guided tour walk, I will be pointing out some historical sights.

Meeting

Meet outside Highbury and Islington underground station (see photo below) from 1.45pm for the walk to start at 2.00pm. See Transport for London

We will finish the walk back at Highbury and Islington.

Please keep your \'RSVP\' updated for this event as it would help me get accurate numbers, and determine who is turning up for the walk; my phone number is Colin 07709 305681.

Weather: Updates will be posted; see also BBC Weather
Please see our weather policy

Walking Safety

Walking is a great way to keep fit and generally very safe; however it does contain an element of risk. Before going on any of these walks you need to be reasonably fit and be prepared to be responsible for your own safety. You must wear appropriate clothing such as proper walking shoes, warm and wet weather clothing and carry sufficient food and water. Please see our Terms and Conditions
item.name: A Walk in the Park

item.description:
Hiya Photographers ~ Next Thursday, March 20th, we\'ll be at the Pizza Factory downtown for a 3 hour class on Adobe Camera Raw and all it\'s intricacies. We\'ll use their back room with the large TV and stream the class from Creative Live. I own the class, so will share it with whoever shows up. Bring your laptops and we\'ll follow along, stopping as needed to try out each tool as demonstrated in the course. If you\'d like to simply watch, without your laptop, please feel free to join us.\xc2\xa0

Note: \xc2\xa0You will need to have either LightRoom or Photoshop installed on your laptop in order to try out the techniques being demonstrated in the class. \xc2\xa0You will not be linked in to the class or connected to the program of the class. \xc2\xa0If you find it useful to own, then you\'ll need to go directly to www.creativelive.com and buy it there. \xc2\xa0(and, no, I do not receive ANY type of comp. for sharing this class with you)

\n\nDate: Thursday, March 20th

Time: 2pm to 5pm

At: The Pizza Factory, downtown P.T.
item.name: Class on Adobe Camera Raw (ACR)

item.description:
Are you interested in fashion?


In Canada Toronto\'s Fashion Week is one of the main fashion events in the country.


Join Sony of Canada at Toronto Fashion Week on March 20th, 5pm.
Join the waiting list for a chance to watch and shoot the Triarchy Show with Sony\'s new Sony A7 and A7R.

This is not first come, first serve, lucky members will be selected from the waiting list on Wednesday March 12, 2014 for the event.\xc2\xa0Toronto Fashion Week is not open to the public and we have limited spots. You will only be able to attend one show out of the entire week.\xc2\xa0

Meet at David Pecaut Square (right next to Roy Thompson Hall) at 4.30pm. If you can come earlier please do, so you can grab your tickets and have a chance to look around before the show starts. Don\'t forget to come back to the Sony Booth at 4.30pm so you can enter the hall. There is only a 15 minute window to enter the show and guests that are late are unlikely to get in.

Also don\'t bring a DSLR style camera since they wont let you take it in. Do bring SD cards so you can save your images.

When you arrive you will see the registration area and at the booth marked "Sponsors" you will find your ticket under your name.

Since Sony is paying for this meetup, only Sony cameras can be used at this event. This event is about trying out the A7 and A7R camera.

Attendance and "No Shows". If you can\'t make the event please cancel 24 hours before the start of the event. If you fail to cancel you\'ll be recorded as a "No Show" and could be dropped from future events.
item.how_to_find_us: Patrick will be at the event
item.name: Sony Photography Workshops, Try the A7 and A7R at Fashion Week

item.description:
http://photos1.meetupstatic.com/photos/event/3/b/8/event_312780952.jpegEvery other Thursday night we\'ll meet up to practice Bird in Flight (BIF) photography. You can also practice other forms of photography, such as Dragon Fly in Flight (DIFF), or Squirrel in Flight (SIF). Just kidding, you\'re welcome to shoot what you want, and instruction will be give when requested.

This a great opportunity to photograph the many herons, egrets and ibis\' as they head to Cooper\'s Bayou to roost. \xc2\xa0Occasionally we see Spoonbills and other species as well. This can provide very stunning shots if the setting sun cooperates.

The PhotoWalks will be scheduled in various parks around the Tampa Bay area that are conducive to shooting flight shots and other photography. The times will vary according to the time the sun sets and Daylight Savings Time, etc. If you know a great location to hold these PhotoWalks, please leave a comment with the suggested location.

There is an optional dinner afterwards at one of the downtown restaurants.

\xc2\xa0

item.description:
Join us for a reception for James Fraher, who is traveling from Ireland to present his documentary photography series, "Down in Houston: A Blues Community Remembered".

He will present a series of Black and White photographs he made in Houston to illustrate the book "Down in Houston: Bayou City Blues", published by University of Texas Press.

He completed the work while living in Chicago. The book\'s author, Roger Wood, will also be in attendance.


Group members will find this a great opportunity to get together, and James may be willing to share his thoughts on living in Ireland with people who are interested.

Houston Institute for Culture is presenting this free event along with HCC and Texas Folklife.

group.name: Houston Museum of Culture Educational Adventures

item.name: Artist Reception for James Fraher from Ireland

item.description:
I will be starting out on the T-bone trail, which gradually makes its way up the mountain. \xc2\xa0I will follow that past the Big Ramada and connect with the Crosscut Loop trail. \xc2\xa0The Crosscut Loop is an easy trail through the rolling low land along Central Ave inside South Mountain Park. \xc2\xa0This trail connects with the Ranger trail \xc2\xa0and then over to the Derby trail. \xc2\xa0Finally, we will connect up with Ma Ha Tauk trail which makes its way up and around the mountain eventually leading back to the parking lot. \xc2\xa0

This hike covers multiple areas of South Mountain Park, giving you a different view around each corner. \xc2\xa0Some sections are flat with great views across the desert plains, other sections drop down in the wash, while others take you up the side of the mountain where cactus and flowers are blooming all around. \xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0

This is an easy hike about 3.5 miles. \xc2\xa0 I try to keep a quick pace and finish in about 1 \xc2\xa01/2 hours. \xc2\xa0

You are responsible for your own safety. \xc2\xa0Please bring plenty of water, hiking boots (lots of loose rocks) and a light. \xc2\xa0We should be back before dark, but it\'s best to always be prepared. \xc2\xa0Watch out for "jumping cactus" as there is one section where it grows along the trail and is looking to hitch a ride. \xc2\xa0I haven\'t seen any this year, but rattlesnakes live throughout the park. \xc2\xa0Pay attention to where you step. \xc2\xa0
item.how_to_find_us: In the parking lot at the end of 19th Ave. (south of baseline)
item.name: West end of South Mountain Hike

item.description:
Gosh.. scheduling this outing against the Juggernaut of Amy and Beth of 30s/40s Social Group is plain foolish on my part.. but playing a fool has never stopped me. \xc2\xa0It is kinda natural.

File Photo - RBH PamIAm

RHB had a \xc2\xa09 mile hike on Caughlin Single Track a week or so ago.


Obviously we can not cover 9 miles in 2 hours, but certainly we can cover the \xc2\xa0jeep trail section in 2 - 2 \xc2\xa01/2 hour.

Great view of the city at sunset.. so.. bring a flashlight just in case we forget the time, and are immersed in the honey glow of evening setting sun and group chatter.

Gosh.. temperature is still predicted to be above normal for this time of the year.. so you cannot pass this by.

Honestly, the hardest part might be finding the trail head as many of the city roads in this area are loops and have very similar names.. Pine Nut, Pine Creek, Pine View, Pine Crest etc. \xc2\xa0What? \xc2\xa0No Pine Sol?

Meetup Place PineHaven & Sierra Pine Drive with first step at 5:30.

So please study the map -- as when you are late because you got lost, we will be gone.

It is not fair to wait for you when we are chasing day light.

If you cannot attend, don\'t worry..\xc2\xa0

Sierra Club has their first after work hike starting Monday (take a look). \xc2\xa0

Make sure you take advantage of what they offer. \xc2\xa0If they follow last years pattern, they will have four hikes in the week with these leaders. \xc2\xa0Monday - Stephanie, Tue - Holly, Wed - Dave Thur - Ridge & Yvonne.

Reno Hiking Meetup Group has an up beat / up tempo Wednesday night hike at Evans Canyon and Lower Peavine. \xc2\xa0I highly recommend that one.

Hey.. call me the maestro, \xc2\xa0as the more they do, the less I have to. \xc2\xa0YeeHA!

group.name: Reno Bike Hikers, Photographers & Outside Activists

item.name: Caughlin Area After Work Conditioning Hike

item.description:
The March meeting will be on Thursday 20 March 2014, from 5:45 to 7:30PM at the Bridge Street Collective caf\xc3\xa9.

This month\'s presentation will be: Patrick Kuiper (bio below) on Sprinting into Agile (web development).


The schedule is:

5:45 Doors open

6:00 Presentation, Q&A, discussion

6:30 Pizza, drinks, korero

All welcome!

There is a ~$5 koha towards catering. For the rest, thanks to our sponsor Campaign Monitor.

We are stoked to have a session on Agile this early in the series. For projects small or large, whether development, UX or even business, Agile is going to be central to a lot of our conversations. And Patrick has plenty of experience with it.

Patrick has 15 years of experience spanning diverse leadership roles in digital publishing,\xc2\xa0 online media, healthcare and IT\xc2\xa0 governance in Australia, Belgium, The Netherlands and New Zealand. He has a Bachelor in Industrial Information Science, an MBA in\xc2\xa0 Marketing and a Pre-Master in Management Science. He has managed development and infrastructure of websites such as nzherald.co.nz, nzww.co.nz, theaucklander.co.nz, thedaily.com.au, tweakers.net, computable.nl, hln.be, demorgen.be, ad.nl, volkskrant.nl, parool.nl, and trouw.nl.


Monthly evening meetings are on the third Thursday of *every* month. The topic is the web, with a focus on either tech, UX or business.
item.name: Nelson Web Meetup Evening Series

item.description:
PORTRAITURE Focus Group(s)

This focus group is being revised and will consist of two types of focus groups; and\xc2\xa0will take place\xc2\xa0primarily in two locations.\xc2\xa0 Chris Williams will be leading these\xc2\xa0groups, assisted by Tim Biddle.\xc2\xa0 Both are excellent photographers.\xc2\xa0 They will trade off the lead position depending on their personal calendars.\xc2\xa0 Several of you have indicated a desire to help in a variety of ways; please be sure Chris and Tim have your name and contact information.

The groups will switch back/forth, depending on the agenda,\xc2\xa0between two main locations:\xc2\xa0 The North United Methodist Church ("NUMC") at 38th & Meridian and the Athenaeum at the corner of Mass Ave and New Jersey.\xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0 It is hoped that we can set up a more permanent traditional style studio at the NUMC location and utilize stage and event resources at the Athenaeum.\xc2\xa0 Other locations will be used on occasion.

Those locations, times, etc. will be posted within the next few weeks.

If you are interested in attending any of these meetings be aware that these are for both beginner and advanced members.\xc2\xa0 This club does not/will not differentiate between those who have/do not have equipment.\xc2\xa0 Basic equipment will be\xc2\xa0available at the studio location.

The mission of this club is that thru a sharing, supportive, and cultural platform, the proficiency level of\xc2\xa0its members will automatically be raised. To what extent, will depend on the amount of time each individual member wishes to invest and exert themselves.

Keep an eye on the calendar, as dates, times, and locations will be posted within the next 2 weeks.

item.description:
\xc2\xa0

Do You Have a DSLR Camera But Aren't Getting The Most Out Of It?

\xc2\xa0

The DSLR Basics & Principles of Photography workshop is a 4 hour information packed session that gets you up to speed with your DSLR quickly and efficiently! This entry level workshop will include both theory as well as practical application of these techniques. Rather than sitting in a classroom, this workshop is hands-on and fully immersive and students are encouraged to ask questions throughout the session.

The cost for this incredible 4 hour workshop is only $25.00!\xc2\xa0 RSVP TODAY


Who Is This Workshop For?


This workshop is for DSLR users looking to get started with their camera and for people who want to learn how to create beautiful photographs using more advanced features of the camera than just the automatic modes.

\xc2\xa0

How Does the Workshop Run?

We will be meeting at a central Toronto location at Bloor/Yonge where we will be participating in the DSLR Basics and Principles of Photography theory session indoors. During the session you will have lots of opportunity to use your camera and put your photography skills to work.\xc2\xa0 Time will also be given for questions and individual attention will be given to assure everyone understands the functions of their camera and the principles being taught.

\xc2\xa0

What Are The Goals Of This Workshop?

The goals are quite simply to help you learn a more about your DSLR and photography techniques to ensure that you learn to make great photos. The idea is to get beyond the point-and-click modes of the camera and discover the creative power of your DSLR.

\xc2\xa0

What Will You Learn?

The DSLR Basics & Principles of Photography is comprised of the following topics:

\xe2\x80\xa2\xc2\xa0When to shoot RAW vs. when to shoot JPEG

\xe2\x80\xa2\xc2\xa0Creative use of Aperture, Shutter Speed, and ISO

\xe2\x80\xa2\xc2\xa0Exploring Program & Manual Mode for creative flexibility

\xe2\x80\xa2\xc2\xa0Learn to use Histograms effectively

\xe2\x80\xa2\xc2\xa0Setting White Balance properly

\xe2\x80\xa2\xc2\xa0Focusing and creatively recomposing shots

\xe2\x80\xa2\xc2\xa0Creative use of fill flash

\xe2\x80\xa2\xc2\xa0Modifying light: bouncing, diffusion and reflectors

\xe2\x80\xa2\xc2\xa0Composition techniques

\xe2\x80\xa2\xc2\xa0When to use the "Rule of Thirds," and when to break the rule

\xe2\x80\xa2\xc2\xa0Framing & setting your subject apart from the background

\xe2\x80\xa2\xc2\xa0And much much more...

\xc2\xa0

Added Bonus Workshop Material:

Full-Colour, 21 page PDF e-book download\xc2\xa0 for mobile devices (pictured on the right)


In an effort to both save trees and go electronic, this 21 page manual is being presented in a PDF e-book format that you can carry with you on your mobile device (iPhone / iPad / Android / Laptop, etc.)

\xc2\xa0

What Do You Need to Bring?


\xe2\x80\xa2 DSLR Camera & Lens(es)
\xe2\x80\xa2 Fully charged batteries
\xe2\x80\xa2 Freshly formatted memory cards
\xe2\x80\xa2 Creativity & Imagination

Summary

Date: Thursday March 20, 2014
Time: 6:00 pm \xe2\x80\x93 10:00 pm
Duration of Workshop: 4 hours
Number of Photographer Spots: 8
Cost: $25/person

Location

We will be meeting at the\xc2\xa0 Plaza II Suites which is located here:

Plaza II Suites
88 Bloor Street East
Toronto, ON
See on Google Maps

Contact Phone Number: Stephen James [masked]

\xc2\xa0

The cost for this incredible 4 hour workshop is only $25.00!\xc2\xa0 RSVP TODAY

Please note that payment must be received to confirm your attendance to the event organizer via PayPal (credit cards accepted even if you don't have a Paypal account). When RSVPing, you will be automatically directed to the Paypal site and then back again to the Toronto Photographic Meetup Group after payment has been processed. Please note that the Paypal site will indicate payment being made to "digitalTouch media."

REFUND POLICY - PLEASE READ CAREFULLY BEFORE SIGNING UP

Refunds for this workshop are only offered if this event is cancelled by the Organizer/Event host. If you absolutely have to cancel, please give as much notice as possible because it allows us to open your spot to someone else who is on the waiting list. Every effort will be given to accommodate you by rescheduling you into a future workshop.

NO SHOW POLICY We have experienced a growing number of people not showing up for workshops, with no notice either by email or phone. This is highly unfair to other people who want to attend the workshop and were willing to, but couldn't because the workshop was filled up. With no notice, we are not able to make accommodation for other people who are on the waiting list. As such, unfortunately refunds cannot be given for no shows on the day of the workshop. It is expected that if you are RSVPing, you have set aside the date and time in question and will be attending. If you need to cancel, please let us know well in advance and every effort will be give to accommodate you by rescheduling you into a future workshop.

________________________________________

About the Instructor: Stephen James

Currently an event photographer/videographer for TD Bank Financial Group, Stephen James is also a freelance photographer specializing in model portfolios, product and commercial images, and is now involved with film production.. Over the last few years, he has also mentored various photographers in the art of both photography and editing.


Stephen James' web site and selected portfolio can be found at: Stephen James Photography. A more extensive portfolio can be found here on Flickr. His growing film archive can be found on Vimeo.

item.description:
The Shanghai chapter of the San Francisco-based Burning Man Project will gather again on Thursday, March 20. Same format as before with a social mix of food and talk at 6 PM before moving on to discussions and plan for the 2014 Satellite Burn and other events starting at 8 PM.

All interested parties are welcome to join. We normally have 20 to 30 individuals, half foreign and half Chinese.

Below is a quick introduction to what Burning Man is about:

Once a year, 50,000 participants gather in Nevada\'s Black Rock Desert to create Black Rock City, dedicated to community, art, self-expression, and self-reliance. They depart one week later, having left no trace whatsoever. The San Francisco-based Burning Man Project is a non-profit renowned for its ability to attract not only the free-spirited and costumed but the elites of Silicon Valley. A few months ago, TechCrunch reported on the participation of Larry Page, Sergey Brin, Mark Zuckerberg, Elon Musk, etc. in the Burner movement.

http://techcrunch.com/2013/09/03/burning-man-founder-is-cool-with-capitalism-and-silicon-valley-billionaire/

The focus settings and controls on a modern DSLR camera can be really confusing, even for pros. I\'ll clarify the whole subject.

\xe2\x80\xa2\xc2\xa0Learn which settings you want to change and which ones to leave at the defaults

\xe2\x80\xa2\xc2\xa0Learn to focus while following a moving subject.\xc2\xa0

\xe2\x80\xa2\xc2\xa0Learn how to focus and recompose.\xc2\xa0

\xe2\x80\xa2 Learn when you can use Depth of Field along with focus and how.


\xe2\x80\xa2\xc2\xa0Learn which button you want to use for focus, it may not be the shutter button.

How to set them and when to set them.

NOTE: You must call the venue, pARTiculars Gallery - [masked] \xe2\x80\x93\xc2\xa0and register with payment first, then come back here and RSVP. Thanks!

\n\nEven a small focus problem makes an image unusable...

item.description:
This free discussion celebrates the diversity of story-telling and the many new platforms indigenous journalists and storytellers now have space on to tell their stories. The discussion will examine the rise of indigenous media into the mainstream and new innovations in storytelling and the implications for coverage of indigenous affairs in Australia. It will also examine the challenges and importance of meaningful collaboration and the experience of non-indigenous journalists in covering Aboriginal issues.\xc2\xa0Please join us after the discussion for drinks and networking with like-minded media and creative professionals at Verandah Bar, 55 Elizabeth Street.

This panel will be moderated by Karla Grant, of SBS Living Black.

Malarndirri McCarthy (@malarndirri) is a senior journalist/presenter for SBS/NITV News. The former ABC newsreader began her cadetship in 1989 and worked as a journalist until 2005. That year, the Yanyuwa woman from Borroloola in the Northern Territory became the Member for Arnhem in the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly. After the 2008 election, Malarndirri was promoted to the Ministry, where she served as Minister for Children and Families, Indigenous & Regional Development, Tourism , Statehood, Women\'s Policy, Senior Territorians, Young Territorians and the Minister Assisting the Chief Minister on Multicultural Affairs until August 2012. She returned to the newsroom in December 2012. Malarndirri won the inaugural Deadly Award for Journalism.


Martin Butler studied politics and economics at Oxford University and then went to work for the manager of \xe2\x80\x98The Who\xe2\x80\x99. In 1981, he migrated to Australia and spent the next 25 years as a longform current affairs television producer for ABC Four Corners, Foreign Correspondent and Dateline. He\xe2\x80\x99s produced two Walkley Award-winners and won the New York Film and Television best documentary award. He worked with Bentley Dean to produce the award-winning Contact, a film about the last first-contact in the Western Desert of Australia. For the past three years he has devoted his life to First Footprints \xe2\x80\x93 a documentary exploring ancient Aboriginal history awarded the 2013 Walkley Award for documentary in 2013.

Kathy Marks won the 2013 Walkley Award for Coverage of Indigenous Affairs for \xe2\x80\x9cChannelling Mannalargenna\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x93 an essay published on the plight of Indigenous Tasmanians in Griffith REVIEW. Her work explored the links between the past and the present, a brutal history that still reverberates in today\xe2\x80\x99s fragmented community. Marks was born in Manchester and worked for Reuters and Fleet Street newspapers before moving to Australia in 1999 as The Independent\xe2\x80\x99s Asia-Pacific correspondent. A regular contributor to Good Weekend, The Monthly and Griffith REVIEW, her work was included in the Best Australian Essays 2010 collection (Black Inc.). Her 2008 book, Pitcairn: Paradise Lost (HarperCollins), won the Ned Kelly Award for true crime writing.

THIS EVENT IS FREE, BUT BOOKINGS ARE ESSENTIAL. Please register at EventBrite: http://www.eventbrite.com.au/e/walkley-media-talk-telling-indigenous-stories-from-beyond-the-block-tickets-9874013440?aff=eorg

item.description:
In order to encourage increased participation in this meet-up here is the challenge.

As photographers we are generally drawn to raise our camera and capture an image because it strikes some sort of emotion. \xc2\xa0We do this consciously (for example in street or documentary photography or portraiture) or unconsciously (as we see a "beautiful" sunrise or sunset and want to share it). \xc2\xa0

For this months challenge the goal is to more consciously think about your feelings when capturing an image. \xc2\xa0We would like you to present one or two images. \xc2\xa0If presenting two then the first should be how the subject looked and the second should be how you felt about the subject. \xc2\xa0These two images could be the same capture with different processing or two entirely completely different interpretations of the same subject / time / place. \xc2\xa0You can also submit one image if you believe it captures both "What You Saw" as well as "What You Felt".

For those who came out to Plaza Blanca you can either submit one or two images from the outing that you feel represents this challenge. \xc2\xa0If not you can photograph any subject matter with the "What You Saw / What You Felt" goal in mind.

Here are the submission guidelines, up to TWO images:

1. RESIZE to no larger than 1024 pixels on the widest size at 72 dpi, sRGB color space.

2. RENAME to your first name last initial, followed by image title. \xc2\xa0For example: \xc2\xa0MichaelT, "image name"

3. Email as ATTACHMENT to emailmpt-a[at]yahoo[dot]com \xc2\xa0-- (replace the [...] with appropriate email attributes).

4. \xc2\xa0Submission DEADLINE is TUESDAY, 18 March by midnight CDT.

5. \xc2\xa0Please email me with any questions or post it in the comment section below.
item.name: What You Saw / What You Felt

This year AIGA celebrates one hundred years of excellence in design. Help kick off the Centennial with a champagne toast, hors d\xe2\x80\x99oeuvres, and dessert at our annual Open House. We\xe2\x80\x99ll be gathering at Nemo Design Studio, together with Portland\xe2\x80\x99s best designers and design advocates, to discuss the upcoming celebrations \xe2\x80\x93 nationwide and in our hometown \xe2\x80\x93 and to share in a conversation on the future of design.
Join us for some happy hour mingling, then listen to exciting plans for the upcoming year. The rest of the night, you\xe2\x80\x99ll have the chance to chat one-on-one with board members, pick the brains of volunteers, and find out more about AIGA\xe2\x80\x99s role in the Portland community.
You may decide to sign up as a member. You\xe2\x80\x99ll likely make some new connections. You\xe2\x80\x99ll definitely come away brimming with ideas about new opportunities within the design world.
So come join us for this special night. Share your ideas and meet like minded creatives. You may even win two free tickets to our much anticipated Design Week event. Details will be announced when we select the winner!

Sponsored by NEMO Design

item.description:
From South Titirangi Rd, we access the coast on the western side of the point via the Tamariki Reserve.\xc2\xa0 We walk towards the point gazing across Little Muddy Creek at the great views of Laingholm Bay.\xc2\xa0 It is very tempting at low tide to just walk over to Laingholm Bay but I suspect the name of the creek in between suggests that while the watercourse may be little, it is probably deeply muddy.\xc2\xa0 So we hug the coast and round Laingholm Point to pass Perkins Bay and Herrings Bay then exit the coast at Davies Bay.\xc2\xa0


We then take a bush track that takes us up to McEldowney Road from which we walk to South Titirangi Road then back to the cars.

The first half of this walk is coastal which makes for a slower pace but the second half is essentially up hill, so you will get some cardio.

Meeting Point: Arama Ave.\xc2\xa0 There is a bustop close to the corner, park further down Arama past the bustop.

Distance: 4 km

Duration: 1.25 \xe2\x80\x93 1.5 hours approximately

Terrain and Pace: Varied, wear grippy shoes, poles will come in handy.

We leave on time in fairness to the whole group.

group.name: Intrepid Auckland Walking Adventures and Beyond

Fruit Splashes and Water Drops!

\xc2\xa0

Bring your camera, flash and fastest lens!\xc2\xa0 This is probably the most fun workshop we\'ve had.

Let\'s practice in manual and shutter priority modes and use them to their full potential, as well as experiment with flash settings and light placement. It\'s a matter of pure luck and good timing!!

We\'ll be dropping a varitey of fruit into water, seltzer water and cream; as well as creating a variety of water drop images using water, cream and food coloring.

Workshop fee $5 pp

What to bring:

Camera, Speedlight, tripod/monopod (helpful but not necessary) appropriate attire that may get splashed if you have a unique plate or dish that will enhance your image, feel free to share.

A macro lens works great but just bring what you have....we\'ll make it work.

Seats will be limited \xc2\xa0so please be sure rsvp appropriately.

A smaller group allows for adequate instruction and timing practice.\xc2\xa0Repeat workshops will be scheduled with enough interest.

Thank You!

~Angela~

item.description:
This is a 4 session class that will prepare you to take the NYS Wildlife rehabilitation exam, usually offered in April. The 1st 3 sessions will be online in a webinar format while the final session will be hands on at the Delevan Training Center on Saturday. You do not need to attend all 4 sessions, but it is advisable to do so as each session gives you better insight into how to be a good wildlife rehabilitator.

This course WILL NOT license you to rehabilitate wildlife. It is just to prepare you for the licensing exam offered by the DEC.

Session 1 will cover how to become licensed and the types of licensing as well as other aspects of record keeping and the "office" side of rehab. We will also cover capture and restraint and admission exam.


Session 2 will cover orphans, adult care, vet care, fluid therapy and zoonosis.


Session 3 will cover habitats (caging), medications, natural healing, release criteria, release and overview.


Session 4 will be at the Delevan Scout Building on Route 16 in Delevan, NY. We will practice tube feeding, bandaging, capture and restraint and handling. This will be a hands on session so you may get dirty. You will be handling live and dead wildlife during this session.

Instructions for joining the webinar will be emailed to you when you pay for a session. Each session will cost $10. If you sign up for all 4 sessions we will refund you $10.
item.name: Wildlife Rehabilitation Course Webinar - Part II

item.description:
No matter how expensive or inexpensive the camera equipment, a properly composed picture can win the awards. In this session we will work to share the guidelines which help make award winning pictures.

In this session, we will branch out into the artistic world, and look at the concepts which make any photograph better.\xc2\xa0 They are the same concepts which artists use when painting and sculpting.\xc2\xa0 Our first class in this group will cover composition.\xc2\xa0 Although having \xe2\x80\x9cthe eye\xe2\x80\x9d is a great asset to possess, there are rules and guidelines which will help you improve your images.

Here is a challenge for everyone attending this class on composition. Go out in the next ten days, and capture a single flower. Compose a shot which uses depth of field to isolate the single flower, and choose an angle which gives the flower a good background. Then post it to our October Beauty in Nature folder for all of us to share.
item.name: 3-20 Photographic Composition

item.description:
For all you creative photographers, let get together and I can show you how to take pictures of smoke.

I will show you how to setup and show you some examples. I will then let you break into groups\xc2\xa0to try it. I will be able to answer your questions as you take your pictures.\xc2\xa0There will be\xc2\xa0how-to videos on editing your photos.

Equipment required

-Camera with manual settings and manual focus.

-Lens: Not overly critical. A standard zoom or kit lens will work.

-Tripod.

-External flash with a sync cord or a remote trigger (I will have\xc2\xa0one available for Canon only). On camera flash doesn\'t work well.

-Barn doors for your flash (I make mine out of cardboard and I will have some cardboard available so you can make your own).

-Remote trigger can be handy so bring it if you have one.

Tolerance to the smell of incense as that\'s what I use for smoke.

I live in a condo and have a meeting room available but we have no visitor parking, only street parking and that can sometimes be at a premium.

Cost: $10.00

\n\nMore Samples:

item.description:
PANEL DISCUSSION - Thursday March 20, 7-9 PM


Why do people buy art? Because they love it, it looks fabulous in their home, or perhaps, they want to re-sell it later for their retirement. Is the term \xe2\x80\x9cdecorative\xe2\x80\x9d a derogatory term, or is it simply descriptive? Can it be both decorative AND a good investment? How do you know which artist is going to turn into a \xe2\x80\x9cgood investment?\xe2\x80\x9d These questions and more will be addressed in the panel conversation between Art Dealers, Consultants, Curators and Collectors.


Featured artists Michael Hayden, Tom Garner, Leon Leigh and MATTEO from \xe2\x80\x9cBest of the West\xe2\x80\x9d exhibit will also be in attendance.


PANEL:


Peter Mays - Executive Director, Los Angeles Art Association & Gallery 825


Sylvia Greer - Art & D\xc3\xa9cor Stylist, Sylvia Greer Artworks

Marlene Picard - Collector & Selector, Photographer & Producer, Picard Pick Art

Moderated by Dale Youngman, Gallery Director & Co-Curator, BOA SOA Gallery

item.description:
\xc2\xa0Let\'s dive into those manual settings and get more familiar with all those DSLR possibilities that may confound many of us! Get your manual out, watch YOU TUBE tutorials, spend time with great lessons on DVD\'s, hang out with your friends who know a lot, crack a book, experiment and ask lots of questions! Get manipulative, hands-on, and give it a go!

***We also need some judges from our most experienced photographers who can help us judge the second and third place winners for "most improved manual use" and "most creative" manual use!***Let me know if you are interested in being a judge. Three judges are probably good!\xc2\xa0

We\'d like to see 3 photos that you really stretched far and away from your normal status quo in using manual settings, whether you are a happy point and shooter, or you already are quite manually versatile and have never used anything but manual. There must be an area of manual skills you have been pushing yourself to achieve! For this forum, let\'s describe in brief notes our manual post processing, whether jpeg or RAW, and go for the manual gusto with aperture, exposure, shutter speed and focus with each shot! As you submit your photos, let us know in the caption what you challenged yourself to do and what you liked about the result. Each of the three challenges should involve different factors of manual settings. REALLY EXPAND your world!

We are adding a friendly contest element to this Forum! Royce Bair is offering a half-off discount to his Alabama Hills Nightscape Workshop, so if you enter your 3 manual photos, (along with comments about your challenge, what you learned and liked, and what your post-processing steps were), your name will automatically be entered in the drawing for receiving this discount.\xc2\xa0

http://www.meetup.com/NightScape-Photography/events/151732262/

Then if you are among the the first place winners, let us know if you are truly interested in this Workshop, and a drawing will be done amongst these 10 first place winners for this half-off discount opportunity.

The 10 first place winners are determined by the highest number of favorable and/or constructive critique comments from other Click members. We\'ll also have a dinner for two coupon or gift card to attend a nice, local restaurant for the Click member with the highest overall number of comments.

The ten second place winners will be determined through numbers of comments plus evidence of stretching of your manual abilities to obvious greater limits as made obvious by your 3 photo submissions. This is equivalent to the "most improved" manual use of dslr over the remainder of March, starting from March 20 to the end of March. (These winners will be entered in a drawing for another prize to be determined (or donated by a sponsor.)

The 5 third place winners will be those with the next high amount of comments and evidence of stretching of their creativity with manual usage within their 3 uploads.\xc2\xa0 \xc2\xa0(These winners will be entered in a drawing for another prize to be determined (or donated by a sponsor.)

Questions about contest aspect? Please ask and suggest--as this is a learning process for all of us and we are open to suggestion!\xc2\xa0 We are also looking for sponsors who may wish to donate gifts for winners!\xc2\xa0

\xc2\xa0The above camera settings image came from this site:\xc2\xa0
http://mikeatkinson.net/Tutorial-4-Camera-Settings.htm

Our Friendly Virtual Forums are conducted in good use of constructive criticism where critique is specifically asked for by the person who submitted the photos. We WILL be using post-processing this time, and please make some comments on your "manual" process or steps to your desired effect--programs used, jpeg, RAW, starting file formats, etc. Protect your artwork with copyright or watermark as desired.\xc2\xa0

Have fun!

group.name: CLICK Photography Club of St. George, Utah

item.name: March Manual Friendly Virtual Forum

item.description:
PP Monthly will be our monthly series of meeting\xc2\xa0covering Post Processing of you photos, Everything that you do after you snap the shutter.

1. Exploring the Develop module in Lightroom.\xc2\xa0 Covering the various tools, sliders and functions to correct and enhance your photos.\xc2\xa0 We\'ll look at how to rescue over/under exposed photos, cover minor blemishes in your portrait, straighten crooked photos, make colors pop or remove them completely and much much more.\xc2\xa0

2. Photoshop Layers. \xc2\xa0A brief Introduction to Layers in Photoshop. \xc2\xa0Probably the most powerful aspect of this software, Layers opens a\xc2\xa0wealth of\xc2\xa0possibilities for photo correction, and digital creativity. \xc2\xa0Get good at this and you might just create art.

If you wish to bring a laptop with Lightroom and or Photoshop installed (you can download trial versions from Adobe) There will be practice files available so you can follow along.\xc2\xa0

100% Free! \xc2\xa0But bring some snacks or drink.

item.name: PP Monthly: Lightroom Develop, Photoshop Layers

item.description:
This is a first for us, due to popular demand (people emailing suggested this amazing model) We have found a lovely model who has graced the runway for Calvin Klein, been a cover girl for the sunshine girl calendar and is a stunning beautiful model from Kitchener Ontario Canada. GO CANADA lol

We will be delving into dark soft glamour lighting for a sensual and sexy lighting set up using local designers clothing smoke machine and with are artful light set ups these images will set your portfolio apart from the crowd.\xc2\xa0


We will also do some great Thunder grey Calvin Klein esque fashion glam sexiness and we will round out the shoot with some High key glam in designer bikini's to make it a balanced shoot adding 3 distinct styles of lighting with one unbelievable model.

We have a SALE on this workshop until March 1st for only $89.95 then it goes back to our regular price of $119.95 for our premium in depth monthly workshop. Sign up today to hold your spot in this amazing workshop.

\xc2\xa0

What we offer from our unpretentious and engaging workshops:

\xe2\x80\xa2 Time is money, and we want everyone to get the most of their experience!\xc2\xa0 That\xe2\x80\x99s why we hold smaller classes; to allow for short, information packed sessions that maximize the shooting time for each participant.

\xe2\x80\xa2 A safe and comfortable, yet professional environment for everyone to gather, network, and of course, to take photos!

\xe2\x80\xa2 An over-head pantograph lighting system to allow for more floor space and faster, more elaborate, lighting set ups.

\xe2\x80\xa2 An array of light modifiers such as; reflectors, umbrellas, soft-boxes, grids, snoots, and beauty dishes.

\xe2\x80\xa2 Multiple, quick, one-on-one sessions with the model(s) to optimize your chances of getting that \xe2\x80\x9cperfect\xe2\x80\x9d shot-\xc2\xa0No turkey shoots!

\xc2\xa0

\xe2\x80\x9cWhat should I bring to the session?!\xe2\x80\x9d

First thing\xe2\x80\x99s first; you need your camera! Any model DSLR camera with a working hot-shoe is perfect!\xc2\xa0*Fresh batteries! (No one loves a dead battery, YIKES!)Formatted memory cards to ensure you can take as many lovely photos as possible!Your favourite lens; anything from 10mm-200mm will work just fine!Don\xe2\x80\x99t forget to bring your passion for great photography and a thirst for knowledge!We will bring the fun! (WOO HOO!)

* In order to utilize\xc2\xa0the off-camera lights for our sessions, your DSLR camera\xc2\xa0must have a working flash hot-shoe for the wireless transmitter. Please consult your manual to see if your camera will work.\xc2\xa0Or feel free to drop me a quick line to discuss it by email.\xc2\xa0 The studio uses\xc2\xa0Elinchrome Flashes and Paul Buff triggers so that everything is functional for\xc2\xa0almost everyone!

Who should take our sessions?

Our sessions are perfect for photographers who have a basic knowledge of their camera and its manual settings (don't worry -we will give you the F-stop and shutter speed for perfect results!). They are also suitable for any level of photographer looking to dive into different styles of photography, learn some great lighting set ups, and have some FUN!

\xc2\xa0Sony/Minolta DSLR Owners:\xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0


ATTENTION!!!! Sony uses a proprietary hot-shoe for their cameras; you will need to bring your own hot shoe adapter to attach to your camera so our studio's wireless trigger can communicate with your camera

item.description:
Are you interested in fashion?


In Canada Toronto\'s Fashion Week is one of the main fashion events in the country.


Join Sony of Canada at Toronto Fashion Week on March 20th, 7pm.
Join the waiting list for a chance to watch and shoot the Bustle Show with Sony\'s new Sony A7 and A7R.

This is not first come, first serve, lucky members will be selected from the waiting list on Wednesday March 12, 2014 for the event.\xc2\xa0Toronto Fashion Week is not open to the public and we have limited spots. You will only be able to attend one show out of the entire week.\xc2\xa0

Meet at David Pecaut Square (right next to Roy Thompson Hall) at 6.30pm. If you can come earlier please do, so you can grab your tickets and have a chance to look around before the show starts. Don\'t forget to come back to the Sony Booth at 6.30pm so you can enter the hall. There is only a 15 minute window to enter the show and guests that are late are unlikely to get in.

Also don\'t bring a DSLR style camera since they wont let you take it in. Do bring SD cards so you can save your images.

When you arrive you will see the registration area and at the booth marked "Sponsors" you will find your ticket under your name.

Since Sony is paying for this meetup, only Sony cameras can be used at this event. This event is about trying out the A7 and A7R camera.

Attendance and "No Shows". If you can\'t make the event please cancel 24 hours before the start of the event. If you fail to cancel you\'ll be recorded as a "No Show" and could be dropped from future events.

We\'re trying to smooth things out with the website and as such I\'m asking for a few volunteers to go through our website and make suggestions.

Your suggestions will be examined and, if possible, put into effect in our website. With that in mind please consider the following. We are not CNN & ESPN with a half million dollar budget and a website staff of 50 designers and programers.

item.description:
This Event Is An Instructional Workshop and Shoot\xc2\xa0

The art of single light photography has a long and storied history and in this workshop we will take a look at the different styles and techniques available for creating compelling and erotic art nudes with a single light and a reflector.

Learn how to control ratio and spill and utilize several different modifiers including soft box, 7\xe2\x80\x9d reflector, honey comb grids and the beauty dish to create dynamic lighting patterns that allow you to use the relationship of highlight and shadow to tell a story and create beautiful artistic body capes and art nudes.

We will employ the services of professional nude models 1 for every 7 photographers and will spend the evening exploring and working in this dynamic and classic lighting style.

Our 1st model will be local performer Jackie Denari

Model #2 Kaylee Ann Holliman

Kaylee is a new face, a petite blonde who I have as yet not worked with yet She is new to modeling so I have no promo photos of her but you will enjoy her


MODEL TIPS

While all models are paid by the organizers for their services at our workshops tipping is acceptable and appreciated by the models and helps to ensure their willingness to continue to provide excellent professional services at future workshops

Cancellations and Refund Policy

If Member cancels we will provide full refund or credit with 72 hours notice or more

71-48 hours notice and we will provide a 50% refund or credit to a future workshop

Less than 48 hours notice and no refund or credit will be provided.

No Show No Notice = No Refund

We understand that at times life throws us all a curve ball we will address emergency cancellations on a case by case basis and will provide refund or credit as deemed proper under the circumstances

item.description:
Make sure to Like our\xc2\xa0Facebook Page\xc2\xa0as that is where all group discussions, contests and other fun stuff happens!\xc2\xa0

This is the introductory workshop I wish had existed when I first started out in the studio. We host this once per month to help new photographers more comfortable in the studio. Working with studio equipment whether it be strobes or speedlights can be somewhat overwhelming when you\'re used to working with ambient light. This workshop will help de-mistify how everything goes together and how to use it. This workshop will cover the essentials you need to know to "technically" set up your gear. Please note, if you\'re looking for tips on shooting models have a look at our other workshops. What we cover in an hour at this workshop can save you all kinds of time and frustration later on by having essential studio lighting knowledge. Like all of our workshops, this one is open to all levels of photographers so come prepared to ask questions and most of all have a great time learning.

WHAT YOU WILL LEARN:\xc2\xa0
- How to use your camera with studio\xc2\xa0equipment\xc2\xa0
- Using a light meter
- Types of lighting modifiers
- What should I look for in a lighting kit?
- How to set it all up and good studio practices

WORKSHOP LOCATION:\xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0
I\'m holding this workshop at LuxSpace Studios at 9 Davies Ave Studio 401 (4th Floor)\xc2\xa0

item.description:
Join us\xc2\xa0this Thursday for another Feet First \xc2\xa0Evening Urban Walk for 2-3 hours as we explore some hidden parks and small bush areas, including going to Chelsea Sugar Factory and\xc2\xa0walk local streets on the Northshore near Birkenhead shops with harbour views at night that are well known to locals for\xc2\xa0its inner city living\xc2\xa0and easy travel to work each day \xc2\xa0! \xc2\xa0.

Guided by Stephen, who has a passion for local history and loves showing visitors to Auckland, some of the backyard treasures he has found in living here for many years.

We're doing this Urban Walk\xc2\xa0 especially for all those that live on the Northshore , or work in the Central City and some members on here, that want to get some exercise in before daylight savings finishes in April.

Open to all members, and guests, but no dogs, or children please.

Have some light dinner before you arrive or bring snacks to keep your energy up., something warm to wear, strong walking shoes or boots, and\xc2\xa0bring a\xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0little head or handheld torch\xc2\xa0.

We'll be exploring Little Shoal Bay, Le Roy's Bush, Chelsea Sugar Works and nearby streets and you'll see some great views of the Auckland Harbour and the Bridge at night, a waterfall that is the largest on the northshore, wetlands, and maybe hear or see some native birds.

You'll also see some beautiful old homes and cafe's and restaurants that this area of the Northshore is famous for...as Hinemoa Street that we walk on later in the evening \xc2\xa0used to the main road, before the Harbour Bridge was built.

Meet 7pm : Little Shoal Bay Reserve Carpark on Maritime Terrace .



\xc2\xa0

Come off Harbour Bridge at Stafford Road if coming over the bridge from the city . Up that road. Right then left into Rodney Rd, then left again into Council Terrace, then look for us on left at little carpark ...by boats.

Be sure to be in the extreme left lane of the clip ons !

About 2-3 hours of walking !

Carpooling : Organise amongst yourselves. Thanks.

Cheers Stephen F.

Mob 0274 77 94 95

item.description:
Okay folks, it has been a long time since we have done a night meetup on the campus of University of Tampa! So let\'s do it!

We have the great beautiful Plant Hall nicely lit and begging for us to take pictures. Since it will be after dark, bring a tripod and if you do not have a tripod, come anyway, it will be an great opportunity to learn how to make the best handheld pictures and learn the power of your camera. We will meet close to the front entrance and set up our tripods somewhere in the park in front of the building and shoot away. Not only can we shoot Plant Hall we also have a great location for the Tampa skyline and I know I will be shooting both.\xc2\xa0

The last time we were at this location, the bugs were terrible, so unless the world changes, bring bug spray! I believe there is parking on campus, just have to make sure we observe their parking rules.

item.description:
Each month, 14 different words and phrases are posted on the brief for the meeting. Each person is free to interpret the words in any way they choose through the camera's lens. You can do as many, or as few as you like. Multiples of the same word is OK too! Just be prepared to show them to the group and and briefly talk about each one.

- How does the image relate to the word? - Where did you take the shot and how did you set it up? or was it candid? - What you like about the shot? - What you would like to have improved?

Remember - someone will bring the laptop if you bring the USB. Prints are ok too though!

The March 14 things are:

1. Letter W

2. Lamp shade

3. Horns

4. Toes

5. Clouds\xc2\xa0

6. Colour Silver

7. Door

8. Saucy\xc2\xa0

9. Spots

10. Meat

11. Confusion\xc2\xa0

12. Hold

13. Two of swords

14. Swings both ways - Robbie Williams

Please note! To defray the cost of running this group ($140 per year) please bring a gold coin for Joseph! :-)

item.description:
The spring equinox is actually around 1:00 PM on March 20 but that is a Thursday and I have to work. I have another Meetup scheduled for March 22 so let\'s try March 21 to get the sunrise in line with the Capitol, Washington monument and Lincoln memorial. Last year we stood at the Lincoln memorial and I thought the Netherlands Carillon might give up a little higher perspective. Maybe the scaffolding will be removed from the Washington by then. Currently it surrounds the bottom 25%.

We will meet around 6:45 with sunrise scheduled for 7:10. There is usually good sky color if it is clear. And maybe it will be a little warmer this year. Afterward I suggest we get some breakfast at Bayou. Best beignets in Arlington.

For the 3rd year in a row - the CHS Photography program has asked for our help providing photography tutors/chaperons for an upcoming field trip. The students will be separated into groups with one volunteer (that\'s us) and 1-2 cameras (provided by the school) per group. Each student will have a portrait assignment that they need to complete during the day and our role will be to provide suggestions and answer questions. This assignment will be the students\' third assignment shooting in manual- so they will need help with that in addition to subject and composition questions.\xc2\xa0


This is an exciting partnership between the CPI and the CHS, and an excellent way to give back to the photographic community of Charlottesville.

All skill levels are welcome, and if there\'s a question you can\'t answer there will be plenty of us around to help out. Please consider volunteering if you can. The field trip will end approx at 3pm. About 60 students will be attending.

While Amelia Island has a rich history itself worth discovery, residents and visitors have an additional attraction to explore at the downtown waterfront March 21-24, 2014.

Two Columbus ships of the famous trio, the Nina and Pinta, are scheduled to sail into historic Fernandina Beach. These floating museums will be available for public tour. The Nina and Pinta will be open for touring from 9 am to 6 pm March 21-24, 2014 at Fernandina Beach Harbor.

One ticket covers self-guided tours of both ships, priced at $8 adults, $6 kids aged 5-16, and kids 4 and under are free (buy tickets upon arrival, look for tent). Groups of 15 or more can schedule a guided tour (special reduced pricing of $5 for groups ages 5 and older, make reservation via their website or call in advance [masked] to schedule).

They have a good record of arriving in port on schedule (95% success rate, according to their website), but sometimes weather interferes, so check for updates and see more details about The Columbus Foundation and the Nina and Pinta on their website.

http://ameliaislandliving.com/fernandinabeach/2014/03/nina-and-pinta-floating-museums-to-sail-into-fernandina-harbor/

item.description:
\xc2\xa0

FCCP

\xc2\xa0

Weekly HDR Photo <strong style="color : #ff0000">Assignment

\xc2\xa0

Week 8

\xc2\xa0

Topic: Bikes

\xc2\xa0

Please only upload one (1) image

\xc2\xa0

The submitted image must be shot

during the week of the assignment.

The image may be upload to the album

after the week of the\xc2\xa0assignment.

Following in the tradition of some of the great photo documentary magazines we are starting a weekly assignment project. Every Friday a new assignment with a topic will be posted. You'll have one week or in some cases less to complete the assignment.

Why HDR? \xc2\xa0Whether you like HDR or not, it's a part of the photographic scene and is a viable art form. \xc2\xa0It is being used in almost all phase of photography and allows for the photographer to apply their own unique artistic touch.

What is an assignment? An assignment is shooting a series of photos that conform to the theme or topic for the week. Then reviewing the photos and uploading the one best photo that meets the requirements of the topic.

Once you have completed the assignment please upload your one best shot to the album created for the event. Please only post one image.

The purpose of a challenge is to encourage members to photograph subjects they may not normally\xc2\xa0photograph. \xc2\xa0By accepting the challenge they'll use photographic techniques and compositional\xc2\xa0techniques that they don't normally use. \xc2\xa0In return, they'll gain new insights and skills in photography.

Here are a few "HDR Bikes" photos to get you thinking.

Please only upload one (1) image


\xc2\xa0

\xc2\xa0

I hope that most or some of you figured it out by know, but the average trail on the western side of the country is mostly rocky and hard terrain with light mud.

As we will be on a tight schedule I\'ll be starting to move half an hour exactly after the meeting time. You are free to "try" and call and catch up with us... no guarantees of course.

Meeting point 12:30 pm at Ramada Dairy Queen (http://goo.gl/O20NEE)
We will then stop at Woqod Mekaines (http://goo.gl/0ox9vs) to fill up our tanks.

I expect we will go offroad at 2 to 2:30, reach our camping spot by 5 pm if all goes well and then start the fun. Way out to salwa road shouldnt take more than an hour and from there another hour and half to doha, so plan accordingly.

As always, please make sure every car is independent with recovery tools, jack, spare tire, grill, food, drinks, and whatever else you might need.

I also need everyone to fill in this online form (http://goo.gl/pPHYYI) prior to the event, even guests who aren\'t registered for the event.

item.description:
The 23 Femme Fatale sold out immediately, so this shoot is an encore occurring before the shoot it encores. \xc2\xa0This shoot is in the afternoon, to help those who prefer daytime shoots.\xc2\xa0

A femme fatale (/\xcb\x8cf\xc3\xa6m f\xc9\x99\xcb\x88t\xc9\x91\xcb\x90l/ or /\xcb\x8cf\xc9\x9bm f\xc9\x99\xcb\x88t\xc9\x91\xcb\x90l/; French: [fam fatal]) is a stock character of a mysterious and seductive woman whose charms ensnare her lovers, often leading them into compromising, dangerous, and deadly situations. She is an archetype of literature and art. Her ability to entrance and hypnotise her victim with a spell was in the earliest stories seen as being literally supernatural; hence, the femme fatale today is still often described as having a power akin to an enchantress, seductress, vampire, witch, or demon, having power over men.

We will shoot in Studio B, and it should be a ball!
item.name: 3-21 Encore "Femme Fatale" with Nicole

item.description:
\xe2\x80\x9cComposition is the strongest way of seeing.\xe2\x80\x9d Edward Weston

I know it is short notice but I have the perfect cure for cabin fever! Let\'s go to Chinatown for a photo shoot this Friday. You have joined the group, now join the fun. After the class we will grab a bite to eat \xc2\xa0in one of the many fabulous little restaurants and look at the photos we have taken. You are welcome to join for that part too if you can. Something different to do on you Friday evening.

\xc2\xa0In this exciting and educational event, you\'ll discover composition techniques that improve every single photo you take from now on.

Do you sometimes wonder exactly where to put the subject of your photo?

Are you uncertain about what should be in the frame?

Are you sometimes disappointed in the shot you get?

Then join us and discover how to capture the beauty of the moment by discovering how to see the hidden structure of the scene. Once you see it, you can shoot it!

This is a "no technical jargon zone", so if you\'re a total beginner, I promise that you will feel at ease and totally comfortable in this relaxed and fun setting. \xc2\xa0

WE will start at the entrance of Chinatown where I will teach you the composition techniques, and then we\'ll all practice what we learned using some fun activities I have designed for you.\xc2\xa0

WE will work with color, line, texture and shape to create visually stunning photos. I always provide hand out cards so you can do the activities again on your own after the class.\xc2\xa0

After a while, we\'ll come back and share our results with each other so you can see the difference in your photos. \xc2\xa0During this time, I\'ll be happy to answer any questions you have and give you helpful feedback if you\'d like. \xc2\xa0Then once you are totally confident with the technique, you\'ll learn how to use it in even more ways.

What makes this meetup unique is that I am NOT going to overload you with a bunch of technical stuff and useless information (we just forget that stuff anyway, right?).

Instead, my promise to you is that you will walk away with three techniques you can use for the rest of your life to take better photos. Even something as simple as a staircase can take your breath away if you get the composition right.

Whether your interests are taking photos of people, nature, architecture, landscape, or even close-up (also called macro photography), this workshop will improve the results you get with every picture by making you aware of some simple guidelines (not rules) for composition.

If you\'d like to take better pictures, then go ahead and put your RSVP in right away.\xc2\xa0If you have taken a composition class with me before, it is still a good idea to take a refresher now and then. Chinatown is a dynamic, visually rich setting for this class and a great place to try out what you have learned.

If this is your first class focused on composition, this class is also perfect for you. I will provide a hand out and step by step guidance so you can clearly understand and apply the secrets to successful composition immediately. We will use rule of thirds, divine proportions, and intuition.

At the end of class we will meetup a bite to eat. This optional social time is my \xc2\xa0favorite part of the session. We get to take a look at your best photos from the day and learn from each other. Good composition is the key to great photography. And constructive conversation is key to discovering what makes some of your photos more exciting than others.

TUITION: $20.

TRANSPORTATION:

The closest T stop is Chinatown on the Orange Line. There are several parking lots near Chinatown. One is across the street in the Leather District, entrance on Beech Street. \xc2\xa0You may also find street parking in the Leather District. It is best not to drive into Chinatown since there is very little parking and you may sit in traffic. \xc2\xa0 You could also park in the lot at the Boston Common and then allow about 20 minutes to walk over to Chinatown.

Looking forward to seeing you on Friday! We are going to have a great time. Hope you will come out and join us. You will be amazed at how much you can learn about how to Take Better Pictures in just 2 hours with this great group of photographers. Please wear something red so I can find you during the class. It helps me keep track of the group. Thanks! Looking forward to seeing you.\xc2\xa0

Suzanne

http://itunes.apple.com/us/book/flow-tography-better-photos/id499049037?mt=11&uo=4

item.description:
Are you interested in fashion?


In Canada Toronto\'s Fashion Week is one of the main fashion events in the country.


Join Sony of Canada at Toronto Fashion Week on March 21, 5pm.
Join the waiting list for a chance to watch and shoot the Madame Moje Show with Sony\'s new Sony A7 and A7R.

This is not first come, first serve, lucky members will be selected from the waiting list on Wednesday March 12, 2014 for the event.\xc2\xa0Toronto Fashion Week is not open to the public and we have limited spots. You will only be able to attend one show out of the entire week.\xc2\xa0

Meet at David Pecaut Square (right next to Roy Thompson Hall) at 4.30pm. If you can come earlier please do, so you can grab your tickets and have a chance to look around before the show starts. Don\'t forget to come back to the Sony Booth at 4.30pm so you can enter the hall. There is only a 15 minute window to enter the show and guests that are late are unlikely to get in.

Also don\'t bring a DSLR style camera since they wont let you take it in. Do bring SD cards so you can save your images.

When you arrive you will see the registration area and at the booth marked "Sponsors" you will find your ticket under your name.

Since Sony is paying for this meetup, only Sony cameras can be used at this event. This event is about trying out the A7 and A7R camera.

Attendance and "No Shows". If you can\'t make the event please cancel 24 hours before the start of the event. If you fail to cancel you\'ll be recorded as a "No Show" and could be dropped from future events.
item.how_to_find_us: Patrick will be at the event
item.name: Sony Photography Workshops, Try the A7 and A7R at Fashion Week

item.description:
The workshop will explore the business and craft of boudoir photography, a rapidly expanding part of the photography market. The first hour (6 pm to 7 pm) will include the business aspects: i) initial meeting with your client, ii) contract and pricing, iii) preparation for the shoot, iv) the photo session, and v) follow up with client.

The second part of the workshop (7 pm to 10 pm) will be a photo shoot with a model to demonstrate lighting and posing for a basic boudoir photography portfolio, including lighting for lingerie, bodyscapes and artistic nude portraits. We will show basic boudoir poses that work with a variety of models, as well as the props suggested for a boudoir shoot.


The model for the workshop will be announced shortly.


We will use both studio strobe and continuous (hot) lights in the workshop, but previous familiarity with studio lighting is not required (but is recommended!)

By the end of the workshop, you will have had an introduction to boudoir photography and a set of boudoir images\xc2\xa0 to add to your boudoir portfolio.

Recommended Reference Material: Christa Meola\'s "The Art of Boudoir Photography." (2013)


Workshop Fee: $ 150 (includes Model Release and use of Pocket Wizard)

Workshop Reservation Fee/Deposit of $25 Required.

Workshop Participation: Limited to 6 photographers.
item.how_to_find_us: The studio entrance is behind 918 O St.
item.name: Boudoir Photography Workshop
