item.description:
During our first meetup, we had the chance to meet everyone, share why we\'re passionate about photography, and discussed what we\'d like to see unfold over time with this group.\xc2\xa0 Everyone was eager to start sharing some of our images so for this our 2nd meetup, it\'s time to start sharing!


It\'d be neat for everyone to share 3-5 images of what YOU like to shoot most.\xc2\xa0 So, if you love shooting landscapes, macro, and your kids for example, bring one of your favorite photos of each type.\xc2\xa0 If you shoot mainly food photography, bring 3-5 of your best food shots, and so on.\xc2\xa0 I think limiting to 3-5 photos will keep things moving.

IMPORTANT:

Please email me the 3-5 images at [masked] if you are not part of our Flickr group (http://www.flickr.com/groups/2594750@N22/).\xc2\xa0 If you are part of the group, add the photos there!


I will have two iPads with retina display for this next meetup for looking at the images. As we go through the photos, feel free to share the "behind the scenes" of the shot and any other relevant info.


ALSO:


Going forward, it might be neat to have assignments or themes where we spend the time apart shooting new images to share for the next meeting.\xc2\xa0 So, it\'d be great if you also brought 1-2 ideas for a future assignment to the next meeting, and then as a group we can vote on which one to do first!\xc2\xa0 Some examples of an assignment or theme might be:\xc2\xa0 textures, black-and-white, trees, etc. There are literally thousands of options so think about it and bring your ideas to the next meetup!


And one last note of housekeeping regarding this next meetup - it\'s at a place called the Filling Station which serves alcohol. I wanted to make this clear in case there\'s anyone uncomfortable with this. I did speak with the owner and he seemed very welcoming of us meeting there. They have wifi and he specifically said that you\'re welcome to bring food there (or have it ordered). They do serve various sodas, fyi.

Look forward to seeing everyone there!
item.name: Picture sharing, etc

item.description:
After a cold & snowy winter, spring is finally here!\xc2\xa0

Come celebrate with us at a great after-work party at\xc2\xa0one of Manhattan\'s most beautiful rooftop venues with indoor & outdoor space on both levels!

Date: Friday, March 21st \xc2\xa0 \xc2\xa0

Time: 6-10 PM

Dress: To Impress

Admission: FREE!

Location: Gansevoort Park Ave. Rooftop!

\xc2\xa0420 Park Ave. South (@ 29th street)\xc2\xa0

*\xc2\xa0Drink Specials *\xc2\xa0

\xc2\xa0$7 red and white wine!

$6 draft beer!

Discounted vodka cocktails!

Party Earth says:

Fashionable patrons taking in the unobstructed view of the Empire State Building from this twentieth-floor hotspot will understand why Gansevoort Park Avenue Rooftop chose "always on top" as its motto.

Sleek and sexy, the space features floor-to-ceiling windows and plenty of sitting areas with suede sofas and wingbacks to accommodate the fashion-industry notables and upscale preppy partiers who gather to check each other out over bottle service.

Clutches of chic Europeans sipping expensive cocktails add just the right jet-set touch to an already swanky scene, complete with the requisite young professionals in tight t-shirts scoping out the beautiful ladies at the brown granite bar.

On warm nights, patrons flock to the spacious terrace to lounge on blue vinyl chaises by the illuminated pool, which features a mosaic of a vintage bathing beauty and is divided into indoor and outdoor sections, allowing guests to dip their toes in year round.

A narrow wraparound balcony bordering two sides of the venue features leather benches and glass floor panels with a dizzying view, while the private Blue Room one floor down offers a true VIP experience that includes exclusive sets spun by renowned DJs.

Stylish party-seekers looking for a combination of upscale vibe, breathtaking views, and a flirty clientele ready to mingle should definitely put this Park Avenue Rooftop on the top of the must-see list.
item.name: First Day of Spring Party at Gansevoort Park Rooftop (Free Admission)

item.description:
This is a 4 session class that will prepare you to take the NYS Wildlife rehabilitation exam, usually offered in April. The 1st 3 sessions will be online in a webinar format while the final session will be hands on at the Delevan Training Center on Saturday. You do not need to attend all 4 sessions, but it is advisable to do so as each session gives you better insight into how to be a good wildlife rehabilitator.

This course WILL NOT license you to rehabilitate wildlife. It is just to prepare you for the licensing exam offered by the DEC.

Session 1 will cover how to become licensed and the types of licensing as well as other aspects of record keeping and the "office" side of rehab. We will also cover capture and restraint and admission exam.


Session 2 will cover orphans, adult care, vet care, fluid therapy and zoonosis.


Session 3 will cover habitats (caging), medications, natural healing, release criteria, release and overview.


Session 4 will be at the Delevan Scout Building on Route 16 in Delevan, NY. We will practice tube feeding, bandaging, capture and restraint and handling. This will be a hands on session so you may get dirty. You will be handling live and dead wildlife during this session.

Instructions for joining the webinar will be emailed to you when you pay for a session. Each session will cost $10. If you sign up for all 4 sessions we will refund you $10.
item.name: Wildlife Rehabilitation Course Webinar - Part III

Wynnum & Districts Chamber of Commerce are holding their annual Barefoot Bowls Challenge over four weeks at Wynnum Manly Leagues Bowls Club just on the Bay at Adam Street.

We were able to field two teams of four the first night .. the Meetup Rockets and the Meetup Maulers (winners on the first night) \xc2\xa0so we need a total of eight - RSVP to secure your place.

You need to be there from 6.30pm for rego/burger and 7pm start. You don\'t need to be there each Friday. We just need two teams of four each time....which we can swap around. $12 per player per night to cover costs which includes a burger / sausage sizzle AND the drinks are cheap. PLUS there\'s prizes on the night and themed nights for those inclined (Superhero night on the FINALS night of 28March).


I took part last year and it was great fun. However I can\'t make it each Friday so am looking for support ...Or just come along on the night for a drink and good company and cheer us on. There will be a raffle raising funds for a special wheelchari for local lad Joel Ventor.

Full details are at: http://www.wynnumchamber.org/website/wp-content/uploads/2014-Barefoot-Bowls-Tournament1.pdf

item.description:
Hi Everyone, And now for something completely different!! On Friday, March 21st, beginning at 6:30 PM, we\'re going back to the 70\'s 80\'s & 90\xe2\x80\x99s for a BIG Dance Party!! This will take place on the Year Round Rooftop Patio at Scallywags located at Yonge & St. Clair.

This will be the first full day of Spring, so let\'s celebrate the end of this harsh Winter with a fun Dance Party on the Patio!!

Come by after work for a bite to eat and or drink to support this great venue. That would be appreciated. After all, Scallywags is giving us this great space for the night, so let\xe2\x80\x99s show our appreciation by supporting them as well. We can either pay as we go or run a tab using a credit card.

So get ready to Dance and Move to the great tunes of the 70\'s, 80\'s and 90\xe2\x80\x99s. We\'ve hired an amazing Disc Jockey to keep things spinning, so it\'s going to be a blast!! Do you have any requests? Just email them to me at [masked] and I\xe2\x80\x99ll be sure to forward them to our DJ. He can also take requests on the fly. The 70\'s, 80\'s, 90\'s music will begin at around 7PM and will go on as long as we\'re still on the dance floor.

We\xe2\x80\x99ll have a lot of space, so feel free to bring as many guests as you wish. The more, the merrier. Everyone is welcome!! This is going to be a wonderful event.

This will be a great opportunity to move to the music and to meet some great new friends. If you\'re a little shy at first, don\'t worry, just see me, Alex, and I\'ll gladly introduce you to a lot of really nice people. That\'s what I do!!

*SCALLYWAGS PUB YEAR ROUND ROOFTOP PATIO (ABOVE)*

So let\xe2\x80\x99s Have Fun, Mix, Mingle, Dance, Unwind and Party on the Patio!! Just remember to bring your sunny disposition, a big smile and a positive attitude. Be prepared have a lot of fun and laughs with a lot of very friendly people.

There is a Meetup fee of $8 to cover expenses, time and the cost of the DJ.

Please see me when you arrive at the 3rd Floor so I can sign you in. Cash only please. Just bring $10 and I\xe2\x80\x99ll have a Toonie ready for you.

Scallywags is conveniently located at 11 St. Clair Ave. W., literally just steps from St. Clair Station on the Yonge Subway Line. When you arrive go straight up the stairs to the top level and I\xe2\x80\x99ll greet you at the door and get you all set.

There are many Green P Parking Lots and Garages in the area!!

THIS PROMISES TO BE AN AMAZING EVENT!!

WE LOOK FORWARD TO PARTYING WITH YOU!!
item.name: 70\'s, 80\'s, & 90\'s Midtown Year Round Rooftop Patio Dance With DJ

item.description:
Let\'s go check out the Boston Arboretum at night. I was assured that we don\'t need to get an official permit by one of the Visitor Education Assistants (but I did give him a heads-up) and I am hoping that we won\'t get bothered by uniformed people. :-)

This will be interesting, as there are no single outstanding features in the park. From the hill at the far end, there is a beautiful view of the Boston skyline and the arboretum itself has a stream, a couple of ponds, and lots of trees. The bare trees make for better and interesting half-obstructed views of the skyline and the challenge is to get some unique sights inside of what essentially is a sparse forest. Spooky branches - light painted, anyone?


We will meet at the main entrance, see address above, there is plenty of parking to the left of it along the street, which should be open (and free) at this time of day.

We meet at 6:45, sunset is 6:55, which means we will get a nice sunset view shortly after the meeting time, just need to hurry to get to that hill in the back. Please be on time for this event, I will not wait! If you are late, I ask you that you stay out and not go on your own, I would like to keep the group somewhat together and enter/leave in a coordinated way. Also, please do text me when you leave, so that I can account for everyone. I will post my phone # in the comments before meetup time.\xc2\xa0

Dress warmly, it will be in the 40s, but with some wind going, making it feel like low 30s. That\'s warm! :-) Bring hot fluids for the night, perhaps a snack or sweets and definitely hiking boots. A variety of lenses, you will have chances for wide angle as well as zoom shots. Bring flashlights and light gadgets! This is a prime opportunity for some light drawing, light painting as well as semi-urban star trails, if it is clear (which is the forecast right now).

If this is a good meetup, we will repeat it in the summer when the trees are full.


Below are some screen shots to give you ideas. Entrance on the right, parking on the left:

The @ sign in the park is the hill, from which you get a city skyline view as shown above.


Pictures from Google maps, Boston archives and a few FLICKR users.
item.name: Arnold Arboretum, Boston

item.description:
http://turongates.com/\xc2\xad

Turon Gates is an authentic bush hideaway, tranquil and unspoilt only 2.5 hours from Sydney. It is located in the Blue Mountains on the way to Mudgee. With 7 well-built rustic log cabins situated along 15km of crystal clear trout stream and 6 cottages with sensational mountain views, Turon Gates has long been an all-year-round favourite holiday destination for many Australian couples and families.

Enjoy waking up to the sounds of the bush, the chatter of the birds and the animals that come to the river for a drink. Turon Gates is abound with wildlife, kangaroos, wombats, platypus, echidnas, possums, bush lizards are all part of the Turon experience!

There is much to do, or nothing to do - the choice is yours (options include hikes, canoeing, horse riding, gold panning, swimming, mountain biking).

Costs:

Camping - $34 per car and 2 people camping per night (ie. $34 per person, based on 2 people)

River Cottage - Sleeps 8. 1 Queen and 6 single beds. $112.50 per person for the weekend.

Mountain cottage - slightly bigger and mountain view. Sleeps 8. 2 Qs and 4 single beds. $127.25 per person for the weekend.

May be able to offer a 10% discount, dependent on numbers (for the cabins).
item.name: Blue Mountains

item.description: Come and learn how to take night photos! We\'ll teach you proper ISO setting, long exposures, creating light trails, and more! We\'ll meet at the top of the Art Museum steps and spend the entire time practicing our night photography. Bring your tripod (a necessity for night photography) and get ready to use Full Manual mode! Make sure to dress for the weather and bring an extra battery - long exposures drain batteries quickly. We\'ll meet at 7pm to catch some sunset shots and stay until it\'s completely dark, so come anytime!
item.name: Night Shooting!

item.description:
Are you interested in fashion?


In Canada Toronto\'s Fashion Week is one of the main fashion events in the country.


Join Sony of Canada at Toronto Fashion Week on March 21, 7pm.
Join the waiting list for a chance to watch and shoot the Stephan Caras Show with Sony\'s new Sony A7 and A7R.

This is not first come, first serve, lucky members will be selected from the waiting list on Wednesday March 12, 2014 for the event.\xc2\xa0Toronto Fashion Week is not open to the public and we have limited spots. You will only be able to attend one show out of the entire week.\xc2\xa0

Meet at David Pecaut Square (right next to Roy Thompson Hall) at 6.30pm. If you can come earlier please do, so you can grab your tickets and have a chance to look around before the show starts. Don\'t forget to come back to the Sony Booth at 6.30pm so you can enter the hall. There is only a 15 minute window to enter the show and guests that are late are unlikely to get in.

Also don\'t bring a DSLR style camera since they wont let you take it in. Do bring SD cards so you can save your images.

When you arrive you will see the registration area and at the booth marked "Sponsors" you will find your ticket under your name.

Since Sony is paying for this meetup, only Sony cameras can be used at this event. This event is about trying out the A7 and A7R camera.

Attendance and "No Shows". If you can\'t make the event please cancel 24 hours before the start of the event. If you fail to cancel you\'ll be recorded as a "No Show" and could be dropped from future events.
item.how_to_find_us: Patrick will be at the event
item.name: Sony Photography Workshops, Try the A7 and A7R at Fashion Week

item.description:
This is really it... this is the last paint session of the year! \xc2\xa0The clocks will go forward this month so we're going to squeeze in one final session. \xc2\xa0

This\xc2\xa0light painting workshop\xc2\xa0covers the basic elements required to creatively utilise different light sources to produce a variety of interesting effects.


You will learn how to construct basic\xc2\xa0orb lights and light rails, be instructed on the proper technique to use them, and you will have multiple attempts to experiment with different colours for orbs and rails.\xc2\xa0 It is anticipated that this workshop will run for 2.5 - 3 hours.

This is a hands-on workshop, members will be shown how to use the lights to produce the majority of the photographs in this session.\xc2\xa0 Organisers are there in an instructional capacity to direct members on what they need to do.

Required Equipment

A camera
A shutter release
A tripod

\xc2\xa0

\xc2\xa0

\xc2\xa0

\xc2\xa0

\xc2\xa0

\xc2\xa0

\xc2\xa0

Shutter release and batteries


Due to the requirements to have a minimum of 45 seconds shutter speed to coordinate the entire group for each shot, and to eliminate the possibility of interference, you need a shutter release cable for this session.\xc2\xa0 Remote controls can interfere with each other so we prefer wired if you have one.\xc2\xa0

Please ensure your battery is fully charged.\xc2\xa0 We advise bringing a spare if possible as long exposures and the cold can eat battery life.


Lens


A standard 18-55 or wide lens is preferable to fixed lenses.\xc2\xa0 A lens with manual and auto focus is ideal so you can lock the focus once fixed.


Skill level

This course requires basic camera knowledge and competence in it's operation.

You should know how:

\xe2\x80\xa2\xc2\xa0set to manual mode and bulb mode

\xe2\x80\xa2\xc2\xa0set ISO and White Balance

\xe2\x80\xa2\xc2\xa0use a cabled shutter release, including setup

\xe2\x80\xa2\xc2\xa0to manually focus

All of these setting are in your manual so if you are unsure refer to the manual and bring it with you if needed. \xc2\xa0

Some post-processing of your images may be required in order to balance extreme contrast ranges, otherwise, all lighting effects are produced in-camera.\xc2\xa0

Bring a warm coat as it may get cold.

Organisers will provide all lights and flashguns and any other accessories to be used.

We know you have a self timer but lengths of timing will exceed self timers and you may not be able to get the full image without a shutter release.

Changing lenses needs to be done in between shots so we don't lose time and you don't miss shots!
item.name: Painting with Light Photography

item.description:
Now that I have your attention, let me tell you about the image that you\'re looking at.

Some months ago Adventures in Photography sponsored a field trip to the Brooklyn Botanical Garden. One of the participants posted the above image. I was so taken with the image that I contacted the photographer that produced this image and asked him to present a workshop on what he did and how he did it.

He (Miguel Mongui) said yes.

I\'m delighted to be able to offer everyone a chance to attend a workshop on Infrared Photography.

This presentation will teach you everything you need to know to take infrared images with your existing camera equipment.

Miguel Mongui, our presenter will share his knowledge and techniques on March 21st, 2014, at the VFW in Saddle Brook, NJ. located at 44 Market Street, Saddle Brook, NJ 07663

Here\'s an outline of what you can expect:

Presentation outline:\xc2\xa0

INFRARED \xc2\xa0PHOTOGRAPHY

This seminar would focus on Infrared photography done with\xc2\xa0 infrared filters. This is the cheaper way to do it since converting a camera will be expensive and permanently, \xc2\xa0meaning that you will not be able to take regular pictures with your camera anymore.

The seminar will be divided in 4 parts:

1) INTRODUCTION

Infrared Photography Introduction

Equipment,\xc2\xa0Camera options (how to check if your camera can capture IR light), Filters, Tripod, Lenses (Issues), Remote release, What and when to shoot.

2) SETTING UP THE CAMERA

We will review camera settings for IR such as white balance, Aperture, ISO, Shutter speed, focusing\xc2\xa0 & stabilization

3) PRE/PROCESSING THE IMAGES

White balance calibration (before post production)

How to download DNG profile editor from adobe labs\xc2\xa0

Converting the image to DNG

Exporting the camera profile

\xc2\xa0

4) PROCESSING IN LIGHTROOM / CAMERA RAW (full demonstration) and

POST PRODUCTION IN PHOTOSHOP \xc2\xa0(full demonstration)

CONCLUSION
item.name: Infrared Photography - A How To Guide

item.description:
EVENT SCHEDULE:

Friday, March 21st, 9 AM to 6 PM
Saturday, March 22nd, 9 AM to 6 PM
Sunday, March 23rd, 9 AM to 5 PM

The Winter Park Sidewalk Art Festival is one of the nation\'s oldest, largest and most prestigious juried outdoor art festivals, consistently rated among the top shows by Sunshine Artist and American Style magazines. In 2013 it was voted America\'s Best Juried Fine Art Fair by Art Fair Calendar.com readers. Each year more than 350,000 visitors enjoy the show. This year about 1,100 artists from around the world applied for entry and an independent panel of judges selected 225 national and international artists to attend the show. The National Endowment for the Arts, The White House, Congress and many others have lauded the Festival for promoting art and art education in Central Florida. An all volunteer board of directors runs the annual Festival, now celebrating its 55th year.

The Winter Park Sidewalk Art Festival was started by a handful of enthusiasts as a community project to benefit local artists and art lovers. The first festival was held on Park Avenue in March 1960. The festival featured original works of art and, after being advertised for just three weeks before the opening, drew 90 exhibiting artists. Over the next decade, the festival grew to over 600 artists and was spread out over Park Avenue from Fairbanks Avenue to Canton Avenue and on all cross streets. For the past 30 years or so, the festival has been contained solely in the park area and currently features 225 artists and 3 emerging artists. A loving art community has created and nurtured a successful festival that looks forward to another 50 years in Central Park.

ART CATEGORIES

There is a wide variety of outstanding artwork. Categories include: Clay, Digital Art, Drawing and Pastels, Fiber, Glass, Graphics and Printmaking, Jewelry, Leather, Metal, Mixed Media, Painting, Photography, Sculpture, Watercolor and Wood.

AWARDS

The artists compete for 63 awards totalling $72,500. The Winter Park Sidewalk Art Festival Committee purchases the Best of Show piece for $10,000 and donates it to the City of Winter Park for display in the permanent collection at the Winter Park Public Library. A $5,000 "Art of Philanthropy" purchase award is donated by The Edyth Bush Charitable Foundation and a $2,500 Award for a Distinguished Work of Art is presented through The Charles Hosmer Morse Museum of American Art. In addition, there are 10 Awards of Excellence at $2,000 each, 20 Awards of Distinction at $1,000 each and 30 Awards of Merit at $500 each.
item.name: 2014 Winter Park Sidewalk Art Festival THIS IS A 3 DAY EVENT

item.description:
I\'m just putting this out there. I\'d like to go do some night shooting downtown, using the Alexandra bridge and a few spots around the Art Gallery, and any others you can suggest or would like to try.

The bridge is usually very heavy traffic during the early evening hours so it\'s best to do long exposures much, much later in the night when traffic has calmed-and there are less people running past making too much vibration, as well the winds normally die down a bit at night too which helps with long exposures.

So my proposal is to get a few people together to go shooting, after midnight on a Saturday night. It\'s always safer in a group to go shooting at night. \xc2\xa0I recommend parking under Rideau Centre. \xc2\xa0The plan is to stick together the entire time and walk back to the parking area afterwards. \xc2\xa0Anybody interested? \xc2\xa0We can meet up on the Mackenzie King Bridge over the canal, and go from there.\xc2\xa0
item.name: Late Late Night Shooting Downtown.

item.description:
Extended Detroit URBEX Outing


Explore the Urban Beauty of Detroit

Come explore abandon locations with us as we tour some of the best churches, theatres, auto factories, schools, and warehouses.


Our extended version includes 2-3 locations

This is a photo tour but you don't have to be a professional photographer. Some members just like to explore..


MCPW will be your guides and host by transporting you to and from the locations. During this time we will offer guidance in composition/exposure if needed and answer any questions you may have


Meet at 6:45 a.m. at Parker Creative Co-op Studio in Royal Oak to leave by 7:00 a.m. We will shoot until 11:00 a.m. and then head back to the studio.


A liability waiver will be required for signature to take part in this outing.

Location of abandoned building will only be disclosed to members who RSVP to this outing.


Motor City Photography Workshops reserves the right to change outing location after location is revealed to participants if access to planned location becomes unavailable due to unforeseen circumstances, and to choose a new location based on availability.


Participants should be in general good health and dress appropriately (layers, boots, etc.) as it could be overly warm or cold inside the buildings. Bring a flashlight/batteries

If you are new to urban exploring, read this page for information to make your experience the best it can be.

CANCELLATION POLICY: If this workshop has insufficient enrollment to run, Motor City Photography Workshops reserves the right to cancel the workshop 48 hours prior to the start of the workshop. If this happens, you will be notified by email and reimbursed in full.


**Be sure to read and review our refund policy**

Go to FaceBook and like us!

Check out our website\xc2\xa0 http://motorcityphotoworkshops.com
item.name: Extended Detroit URBEX Outing- Explore the Urban Beauty of Detroit

item.description: This is a wonderful place to really get close to nature. I am setting this meetup to be on the second weekend that they open the gates. I feel the first weekend so many have been waiting to go here it may be crowded. First question always asked is "how long a lens do I need" answer bring what you own and use it accordingly. Make your shots fit your lens not the other way around. A 70-200 is good for "shots of nest building" a 300 mm will get you in for personal shots of each bird....any thing larger will of course get up personal with even the chicks when they hatch. This early will most likely be nest building and bringing in twigs ect to build the nest. Meaning BIF for sure. So be ready to "pan" to get these shots. You will need to pay $7 for a day pass or get a patch for $25 for as many times as you like to come back.

item.description:
Join the Front Range Photography Group for a special tripod session at the Forney Transportation Museum (before hours!).


The Forney has a wonderful collection of over 500 exhibits relating to transportation.\xc2\xa0 You will be able to photograph antique cars, buggies, carriages, one of the world\'s largest steam locomotives, steam tractors, bicycles, tricycles and so much more.

We will have access to the museum prior to opening hours on Saturday.\xc2\xa0 This means we can bring tripods for long exposure shoots that are necessary due to the low light in the museum.

The Forney Museum has a photography policy that requires photos used for commercial purposes to be accredited to the museum.\xc2\xa0 Prior to entering FRPG will provide you with these rules and require you to sign an acknowledgement.

To cover the cost of this event we need a minimum of 15 participants with a maximum of 25 at a fee of $10.60/pp


Please RSVP and pay your fee. We shall see you then!
item.name: Photo Shoot at the Forney

Tickets can be purchased online with a discount. If you prefer to pay at the gate, adult tickets are $20, but you can pick up a $3 discount coupon at Walgreens\'. There are also discounts for seniors 65+, military, and children 6-12. Be sure to bring spending money as no outside food or beverages are allowed.

item.description:
Our own FRPM member, David Brown Eyes has been photographing Powwows all over the western states.\xc2\xa0 His images are full of motion and color capturing the traditional dance.\xc2\xa0 Join David when the Pow Wow comes to Denver.\xc2\xa0 David will be available early morning at McDonalds to go over Pow Wow protocol, heritage\xc2\xa0 and answer any other questions you might have about photographing this interesting event.


Meet at 8:AM for breakfast McDonalds on 4490 Washington Street

Leave McDonalds at 9:30 a.m. or so.\xc2\xa0 Those wanting to carpool could make arrangements at this time in order to save parking fees at the Colosseum.


Arrive at the Colosseum around 10 to get tickets, look around and get settled in. select a meeting spot etc. \xc2\xa0Saturday is very crowded with dancers and spectators. acquire photo passes in time for Grand Entry

Grand Entry is at 11 or so, may get a good introduction to Indian time.


There will be food available, standard area type stuff and also an Indian Taco/Fry Bread stand. \xc2\xa0I many times bring my own food with me.

Full schedule of the event is here.

http://www.denvermarchpowwow.org/DMPW_Website/schedule.html

COSTS:
Front Range Meetup will not be collecting fees, you will pay as you go:


Day pass for Denver March Powwow $7.00

Parking $5.00 \xc2\xa0- not confirmed, might be $10.00

Photography pass - $30.00

I would suggest bringing a fast zoom lens. \xc2\xa0 I will be renting a 70 - 200 F/2.8 \xc2\xa0The light quality in the Colosseum is very poor.

As long as the dancers are in the dance area there is no need for model releases

Powwow is a family event!

Questions?\xc2\xa0 Ask away here...

item.description:
Please read the entire description before signing up for this snowshoe hike.


This route will have lots of views! This is weather-dependent & will be cancelled if conditions are not stable. We\'ll hike as far as the group is comfortable with, without worrying about getting to a destination.
If you need to rent snowshoes, please do that in advance, REI has inexpensive rentals. Pick the MSR ones if given an option.

More info on WTA site:

Location:\xc2\xa0 Mt. Rainier National Park - Narada Falls
Distance:\xc2\xa0 7 miles roundtrip
Elevation:\xc2\xa0 560 feet gain to a high point of 5100 feet
Avalanche Hazard:\xc2\xa0 Avoid the high avalanche danger up the steep slope from the parking lot; low-moderate otherwise.
Maps: Green Trails Mount Rainier East No. 270 (available at REI)


http://www.wta.org/go-hiking/seasonal-hikes/winter-destinations/snowshoeing-mt.-rainier

This is fine for beginners if you have the right gear and clothing.

$: Plan on having cash to split the cost of gas and permit. This will be $32.00, split among participants.

Clothing:

For clothing, you\'ll need fast-drying layers topped with either a softshell jacket or waterproof shell jacket and gaiters to keep snow out of your boots. For your upper body I recommend a short-sleeve running shirt, a long sleeve, long-underwear style shirt, a windbreaker, a puffy jacket and the rain jacket. For hands, bring tight-fitting liner gloves and some insulated outer gloves or mittens. (no cotton, please). Rain pants, softshell pants or ski pants will work.

For your feet, wear wool or synthetic socks & if it\'s warmer than 25 degrees, waterproof hiking boots are fine. If it\'s colder than 25, I recommend insulated, snug-fitting hiking boots.


Bring a neck gaiter or a balaclava and a warm hat. Sunglasses are required.


Gear: have a daypack with food, dry base layers, dry socks, first-aid kit, water in insulated containers, emergency blanket/sleeping bag /lightweight tarp. Bring an insulated butt pad for breaks/lunch. If you have a compact avy shovel and probe, it would be a good idea to have it in your pack.


Please pack lunch, extra water and snacks for the car ride.


In addition to the things I\'ve mentioned, please make sure you have the Ten Essentials, here is a link to the list:

http://www.rei.com/learn/expert-advice/ten-essentials.html

Do not sign up for this trip if you do not have appropriate gear and clothing.


I recommend using NOAA to check the weather at Paradise before you plan your clothing for the day.

Bringing friends: If you want to bring a friend, they are welcome, please have them sign up individually so that Meetup keeps a correct tally of the number of participants. If you change your mind, please RSVP "no" to open your spot up to someone else. This trip is limited to four people.


Deadline: Please RSVP by 6 PM the day before, sign-ups close after that.


Liability Waiver/Disclaimer:

I am not technically a "leader", we are a self-led walk/hike where each person is responsible for themselves.

I am not a professional guide and do not have certified training or insurance. As you are aware, inherent hazards and risks are associated with hiking and all other physical activity.

You are responsible for your own safety and health.

Signing up for this walk/hike means you agree with the waiver.
item.name: SAT. 3/22 Snowshoe @ Rainier, Narada Falls to Reflection Lks. meet @ 8:00 am

item.description:
Do you like old steam engines/locomotives?\xc2\xa0

\xc2\xa0At the Pacific Southwest Railway Museum in Campo, there are over eighty major pieces of railroad equipment, including steam and diesel locomotives, passenger cars, freight cars and cabooses are available for inspection and interpretation.

Like a train ride also?

Golden State is a 12 mile round trip train trip from Campo through the back country mountains of San Diego County to the International Border Tunnel at Division, which lasts about 1 to 1\xc2\xbd hours. Train tickets include admission to the Railway Museum grounds and Display Building at Campo.

The cost is $15.00. The tickets can be purchased online or at the train depot in Campo. \xc2\xa0You can check out the website formore info. \xc2\xa0http://www.sdrm.org/\xc2\xa0We will be taking the 11:00am train ride.

It is approx 1 hour drive time from Mission Valley Grantville Trolley Station, which is at Highway 8 and highway 15. Carpooling is recommended. \xc2\xa0Please mention in your RSVP if you are driving.

We can meet at the Grantville Trolley Station at 8am and leave by about 8:30am.

Pack a lunch/snacks/water. The weather should be nice. Bring sun screen and a jacket.

We have the option of going to the Motor Transport Museum also, which is about 2 miles away.\xc2\xa0http://www.motortransportmuseum.org/index.htm\xc2\xa0and I have been told that they LOVE photographers :).

item.description:
I figure that my first class will be Intro to Photography. It will have 150 pages of info along with a PowerPoint presentation. There will be table and chairs for everyone\xc2\xa0along with a big screen TV.\xc2\xa0Water and light snacks will be provided. There will be not only the info below that I will go over, but people will actually see just about everything mentioned below. It won\xe2\x80\x99t be an in-depth class on everything but the people should come out with a better understanding about all aspects of photography. It will be a 4 hour session and cover the following:

\xe2\x80\xa2 What is a Digital Photograph
\xe2\x80\xa2 Why go Digital
\xe2\x80\xa2 3 Steps of Digital Photography
\xe2\x80\xa2 How a Digital Camera Works
\xe2\x80\xa2 Steps in Buying a New Camera and other Equipment
\xe2\x80\xa2 Types of Digital Cameras
\xe2\x80\xa2 Camera Controls
\xe2\x80\xa2 Composing Images
\xe2\x80\xa2 Continuous Shooting
\xe2\x80\xa2 Shooting Movies
\xe2\x80\xa2 Image Sensors \xe2\x80\x93 size, resolution, aspect ratio, sensitivity
\xe2\x80\xa2 Image Formats
\xe2\x80\xa2 In-Camera Storage \xe2\x80\x93 type, sizes, speeds
\xe2\x80\xa2 Playback Mode
\xe2\x80\xa2 Transferring Images
\xe2\x80\xa2 Lenses \xe2\x80\x93 focal length, aperture, depth-of-field, image stabilization, accessories
\xe2\x80\xa2 Exposure Modes \xe2\x80\x93 auto, program, aperture, shutter, manual, bulb, custom
\xe2\x80\xa2 Histograms & Highlight Warnings
\xe2\x80\xa2 Focusing
\xe2\x80\xa2 White Balance and Color Spaces
\xe2\x80\xa2 Flash Photography \xe2\x80\x93 on and off camera, curtain sync, slaves
\xe2\x80\xa2 Batteries
\xe2\x80\xa2 Other Camera Features
\xe2\x80\xa2 Studio Equipment
\xe2\x80\xa2 Portrait & Product Photography
\xe2\x80\xa2 Other Camera Equipment
\xe2\x80\xa2 Flash Accessories
\xe2\x80\xa2 Image Storing & Viewing
\xe2\x80\xa2 Camera Straps & Bags
\xe2\x80\xa2 Caring for your Camera
\xe2\x80\xa2 Glossary of Camera Terms

\xe2\x80\xa2\xc2\xa0Links to sites that could be helpful

\xe2\x80\xa2\xc2\xa0Rules of Thumb

There are no prereqs for this class. The cost will be $30 cash at the door or $35 for credit cards. The topics will not be in-depth studies but after the course, you should know just about everything there is on Photography. You don\'t have to be a club member, you can bring a friend if you want.

There will be a limit of 15 people. If I get more, I will hold another class.
item.name: The Basics of Photography - Photography A-Z

item.description:
Walter Jones Historical Park is located at 1194 Mandarin Road, Jacksonville. The park boasts ancient live oak trees draped with Spanish moss and sits on the edge of the St. Johns River. We will meet in the parking lot at 8 a.m.\xc2\xa0

Step into the 10-acre Walter Jones Historical Park and experience the essence of post-Civil War Mandarin in Jacksonville, FL. Walter Jones, an immigrant from England, purchased this farm in about 1902 from the estate of its original owner, William W. Webb. Jones became postmaster of Mandarin and located the post office in his general store, which he and his descendants operated from 1911 to 1964. The store, which has been converted into a museum, is about a mile past the park on Mandarin Road. The city of Jacksonville purchased the property in 1994.\xc2\xa0

Leader: Carole Adams, [masked]
item.name: Walter Jones Park Field Trip

Come together for a coffee, breakfast and a stroll through town with camera in hand. When finished, process and upload your photos to our Flickr group with the tag, \'Breakfast Club.\'

item.description:
Ever wonder what the early Native Americans thought or believed about dinosaur tracks? We know there are dino tracks all over the southwest, and for that matter, all over the world! But how many petroglyphs or pictographs depict the presence or show any imagination in the art of these ancient people about these obviously HUGE creatures?

The \'Thunderbird Footprints\' at Flag Point near Kanab may be the only known site in North America with convincing imagery showing the ancient peoples\' thoughts and beliefs about these dino tracks.

Rating:
Strenuous
3+ miles
1000 feet or more of climb
Some very steep sections, one rope assist
Altitude between 5300 and 6300 feet

The Drive:
2 hours to the trailhead, with 4 miles on smooth dirt.

The Hike:


This hike features a moderately strenuous 1000 ft elevation climb over a distance of about a mile, to the top of the Vermillion Cliffs. Additionally there is much potential hiking once on top in both directions along the cliff top. Expect a total distance of only three miles for the minimal route, plus whatever extra hiking is tacked on up top.

Most of the climb is on ever steepening dirt and rock slopes, followed by many cliff bands that require long zig-zags to pass. The footing is mostly fairly good due to the many pinyon pines holding the soil and boulders in place. However, the climb also includes about 30 vertical feet of very steep, 45 degree slickrock with moqui steps and natural handholds. It\'s the only way to the top, and requires considerable agility and arm strength, along with good balance. It\'s not quite \'stemming,\' but some arm bracing is needed to make the top of the incline.

The last four feet of this section are up over some waist high ledges where the falling exposure is fairly high, due to the lack of good handholds. Very agile people can easily make it, so our lead climber will take a rope and anchor it around a thick tree above to give secure grip at this point. Be aware tho that a fall here could be fatal, and if you are not confident in your general rock climbing skills, please don\'t attempt this hike.

As always, by agreeing to join us on this hike you assume full responsibility for your safety and well-being, as do any guests you may bring. If in our opinion we feel a participant is not physically qualified to do this hike safely, we we will ask those person/s not to attend.

After all that climbing, our reward is a visit to multiple rock art sites, as well various dinosaur trackways. The 360 views stretch all the way to Navajo Mountain to the south, Zion in the northwest, the Bryce cliffs to the north, and the Vermillion Cliffs stretching off east and west over the horizon.

Hiking on top is wide open as well. Near at hand are additional trackway sites to hunt out and a 150 foot hill climb right near the cliff edge for the really big view. For the longer legged hikers, Flag Point itself is within reach only one mile distant.

Driving:
The drive is 1.5 hours to Kanab, then 13 miles east on Hwy 89 to Seaman Canyon Road (good dirt) and 4 more smoothish miles to the trailhead. High clearance vehicles are recommended here, but you could get by with almost anything.

Prep:
Wear sturdy hiking shoes, light layers from t-shirt to light jacket for winds, bring lunch for our primo lunch spot, 2 liters of water, hiking sticks, gloves, and camera!

Suggestion:
Since the drive from St. George to the trailhead is 2 hours, you may want to consider staying in Kanab to enjoy another hike the next day. There are SO many great hikes in this area! Organize any carpooling accordingly, and we recommend paying your carpool driver about $15 for gas and wear and tear on the vehicle.

See you there!

and

item.description:
The North End provides countless opportunities to photograph buildings, people, unique details, food, and a way of life. Join us for this photo walk throughout the North End and be exposed to the rich photographic material that surrounds your senses.

We will meet at the front entrance to the Old North Church and Jean will lead you on a walking tour of the North End, pointing out unique characteristics and helping you get great shots that will range from the unique character and characters of the North End to iconic shots of Boston.

We\'ll be taking pictures throughout the day but scheduled photo \'stops\' will include:\xc2\xa0

\xe2\x80\xa2\xc2\xa0Old North Church

\xe2\x80\xa2 Paul Revere statue and \'mall\'

\xe2\x80\xa2\xc2\xa0Copp\'s Hill Burying Ground

\xe2\x80\xa2 Polcari\'s - a smell and sight explosion as they sell fresh-ground coffee, herbs by the scoop, fresh pasta, beans and more - all done the old-fashioned way.


At 11am we will invade Pizzeria Regin

a for an early lunch and dine on some of

the best pizza in town! (Lunch is not included with registration fee. Please bring cash to cover your lunch expenses!)


After lunch we will continue on to the Paul Revere House and get a glimpse of the Custom House tower. We will end our gathering on Hanover Street and visit Salumeria, a store with amazing meats, cheeses, olives and olive oil. And then finally we will pay a visit to Mike\'s Pastry where everyone will be treated to a cannoli. (A cannoli is included in your registration fee.)

PARKING: There are several places to park near the North End but the one I usually use is at Lewis Wharf, 28 Atlantic Ave. It\'s just a short walk to the North End from that parking area. Also close by is Sargeant\'s Wharf at 269 Commercial St. (See the MAP here.)


This Meetup is limited to 12 participants, so register early. If it rains, the rain date is March 29.

item.description:
THE BLUE ANGELS ARE BACK!!!\xc2\xa0

We are excited to host the U.S. Navy Blue Angels as part of our inaugural event, Friday, March 21 and Saturday, March 22, 2014 at Fox Field. Air Show fans will be captivated by\xc2\xa0an array of exciting and thrilling jets, gravity-defying aerobatic performers and the rumble of historic aircraft. We\xe2\x80\x99ll have something for everyone in the sky and on the ground!


Buy your tickets here ($20)

The Blue Angels demonstrate the precision taught to all naval aviators while flying less than 36 inches apart in the four-plane diamond, echelon and six-plane delta formations, while the opposing solos demonstrate the power and maneuverability of the Navy\xe2\x80\x99s elite strike fighter, the Boeing F/A-18 Hornet. A special performance by their Lockheed C-130 support aircraft, affectionately known as \xe2\x80\x98Fat Albert\xe2\x80\x99, will also be part of the show.\xc2\xa0Buy your tickets\xc2\xa0today to see the Blue Angels rock the skies of LA County!

For additional performer images\xc2\xa0visit our\xc2\xa0In the Sky performer\xc2\xa0or\xc2\xa0Media Approved Images\xc2\xa0pages.

Spectators will also enjoy thrill-seeking performances from the\xc2\xa0Red Bull Air Force\xc2\xa0including former two time Red Bull Air Race World Champion and five time U.S. National Aerobatic Champion,\xc2\xa0Kirby Chambliss,\xc2\xa0the Red Bull Air Force wingsuit flyers, and\xc2\xa0Chuck \xe2\x80\x98Malibu\xe2\x80\x99 Aaron,\xc2\xa0known as a methodical risk taker and the first civilian ever to be licensed to perform helicopter aerobatics in the U.S. Aaron has also been inducted into the Society of Experimental Test Pilots and is recognized officially as a Living Legend of Aviation.

As part of the Red Bull performance, Kirby Chambliss will fly one of his explosive aerobatic routines in conjunction with the wingsuit flyers creating an aviation circus-like performance in the sky by some of the world\xe2\x80\x99s top extreme athletes.

The Air Show will showcase thrilling jets, world-renowned aerobatic performers, warbirds, and vintage aircraft that will inspire both young and old to dream big.\xc2\xa0 Performers include (but not limited to):

The U.S. Navy\xc2\xa0light Demonstration Squadron, the Blue AngelsSpecial performance by the Blue Angels Lockheed C-130 support aircraft, affectionately known as \xe2\x80\x98Fat Albert\xe2\x80\x99Red Bull Air Force \xe2\x80\x93 Including Chuck Aaron in his aerobatic helicopter, Kirby Chambliss flying gravity-defying aerobatics in his Edge 540, and the Red Bull Wing Suit FlyersGreg Colyer \xe2\x80\x93 The Ace Maker featuring the iconic Lockheed T-33 Shooting StarBill Braack \xe2\x80\x93 Smoke N\xe2\x80\x99 Thunder Jet Car, racing close to 400 mphHeritage Flight \xe2\x80\x93 P-51 Mustang and F-86 Sabre JetLockheed P-38 Lightning Aerobatic DemonstrationKorean War Demonstration \xe2\x80\x93 featuring a dogfight between an F-86 Sabre Jet and a Mig 15Northrop N9MB Flying Wing flyoversAnd, so much more!


Check out the special PHOTO PASS available to photographers!\xc2\xa0
item.name: LA County Air Show 2014

item.description:
** Non-organizer led event. **

This is not an official organizer led event but it is an opportunity for you to get out there and shoot something different. If you attend please share your photos so we can share in your experiences.

"Artists will entertain throughout the day with their traditional and modern Scottish tunes. The wee lads & lassies area will entertain our younger visitors.

We will also showcase competitive highland dancing, pipe bands, heavy athletics, country dancing, historical re-enactments, vintage British car exhibitions and representatives of over 50 Clans."

Saturday March 22nd 9am - 7pm

Sunday March 23rd 9am - 4pm

item.description:
Natural Bridge Trail Trek Series

Natural Bridge State Resort Park
DATES & TIMES
Mar 22, 2014 9:00 A.M. - 2:00 P.M. Apr 26, 2014 9:00 A.M. - 2:00 P.M. Jun 07, 2014 9:00 A.M. - 2:00 P.M. Sep 27, 2014 9:00 A.M. - 2:00 P.M. Nov 08, 2014 9:00 A.M. - 5:00 P.M.

LOCATION
2135 Natural Bridge Rd., Natural Bridge State Resort Park, Slade, KY 40376 Phone: [masked] Email: [masked] parks.ky.gov/parks/resortparks/natural-bridge
ABOUT
Discover the beauty of Natural Bridge on one or more of our naturalist-led hikes in the Natural Bridge Trail Trek Series. Complete all five guided hikes (over 25 miles) in this series and you will have hiked all of the trails at Natural Bridge State Resort Park and will receive a free Trail Trek T-shirt! This is a great way to truly experience the rugged cliff line, rock shelters, arches, plants, and animals of the park!

Where: Meet at the Hemlock Lodge lobby at 9a.m. for each trek.

Fee: $8 per person, per trek. Who: Ages 10-17 must be accompanied by an adult. Min. age: 10 Registration: Space is limited and pre-registration is required. The registration deadline is one week before the date of each trek. Contact: Brian Gasdorf at [masked] or [masked] with the trek date, your name, phone #, email address, and number of people in your party. Payment is not due until arrival. Prepare: Dress for the weather. Pack water, snacks & sack lunch.

Length of Treks: Ending time for the first four treks will be around Noon - 2pm. The November 8th trek will end around 4pm - 5pm.

Trek Dates and Trail Distances:
March 22nd - 4 miles
April 26th - 4 miles
June 7th - 4 miles
September 27th - 5 miles
November 8th - 8 miles Note: Treks may be cancelled if severe weather is forecast.
item.name: Natural Bridge Trail Trek Series
